div.p: The English traveller. As it hath been publicly acted at the cockpit in Drury-lane: by her majesty's servants.
London, printed by Robert Raworth: dwelling in old Fish-street, near saint Mary Maudlin's church. 1633.

list.item: Roger the clown servant to old Wincott.
Old Lionell a merchant father to young Lionell.
Old Mr. Geraldine father to young Geraldine.
The owner of the house, supposed to be possessed.

div.head: To the right worshipful sir Henry Appleton, knight baronet, etc.
div.p: For many reason I am induced, to present this poem, to your favourable acceptance; and not the least of them that alternate love, and those frequent courtesies which interchangeably passed, betwixt yourself and that good old gentleman, mine uncle (Master Edmund Heywood) whom you pleased to grace by the title of father: I must confess, I had altogether slept (My weakliness and bashfulness discouraging me) had they not been wakened and animated, by that worthy gentleman your friend, and my countryman, sir William elvish, whom (For his unmerited love many ways extended towards me,) I much honour; neither sir, need you to think it any undervaluing of your worth, to undertake the patronage of a poem in this nature, since the like hath been done by Roman Laelius, Scipio, Maecenas, and many other mighty princes and captains, nay, even by Augustus Caesar himself, concerning whom Ovid is thus read, detristi: lib. 2.
div.l: Inspice ludorum sumptus auguste tuorum
Empta tibimagno, talia multa leges.
Haec tu spectasti, spectandaque saepe de desti
Maiestas adeo comis ubique tua est.
div.p: So highly were they respected in the most flourishing estate of the Roman empire; and if they have been vilefied of late by any separistical humorist, (As in the now questioned histriomastix) I hope by the next term, (Minerva assistente) to give such satisfaction to the world, by vindicating many particulars in that work maliciously exploded and condemned, as that no gentleman of quality and judgement, but shall therein receive a reasonable satisfaction; I am loath by tediousness to grow troublesome, therefore conclude with a grateful remembrance of my service intermixed with myriads of zealous wishes for your health of body, and peace of mind, with superabundance of earth's blessings, and heaven's graces, ever remaining;

div.head: To the reader.
div.p: If reader thou hast of this play been an auditor? there is less apology to be used by entreating thy patience. This tragicomedy (Being one reserved amongst two hundred and twenty, in which I have had either an entire hand, or at the least a main finger, coming accidentally to the press, and I having intelligence thereof, thought it not fit that it should pass as filius populi, a bastard without a father to acknowledge it: true it is, that my plays are not exposed unto the world in volumes, to bear the title of works, (As others) one reason is, that many of them by shifting and change of companies, have been negligently lost, others of them are still retained in the hands of some actors, who think it against their peculiar profit to have them come in print, and a third, that it never was any great ambition in me, to be in this kind volumniously read. All that I have further to say at this time is only this: censure I entreat as favourably, as it is exposed to thy view freely. ever
div.signed: Studious of thy pleasure and profit, Thomas Heywood.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: A strange play you are like to have, for know,
We use no drum, nor trumpet, nor dumb show;
No combat, marriage, not so much today,
As song, dance, masque, to bombast out a play;
Yet thèse all good, and still in frequent use
With our best poets; nor is this excuse
Made by our author, as if want of skill
Caused this defect; it's rather his self will:
Will you the reason know? There have so many
Been in that kind, that he desires not any
At this time in his scene, no help, no strain,
Or flash that's borrowed from another's brain;
Nor speaks he this that he would have you fear it,
He only tries if once bare lines will bear it;
Yet may't afford, so please you silent sit,
Some mirth, some matter, and perhaps some wit.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter young Geraldine and master Dalavill.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: O friend, that I to mine own notion
Had joined but your experience; I have the
Theoric, but you the practice.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I perhaps, have seen what you have only read of.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: There's your happiness.
A scholar in his study knows the stars,
Their motion and their influence, which are fixed,
And which are wandering, can decipher seas,
And give each several land his proper bounds;
But set him to the compass, he's to seek,
When a plain pilot can, direct his course
From hence unto both th'indies; can bring back
His ship and charge, with profits quintuple.
I have read Jerusalem, and studied Rome,
Can tell in what degree each city stands,
Describe the distance of this place from that,
All this the scale in every map can teach,
Nay, for a need could punctually recite
The monuments in either; but what I
Have by relation only, knowledge by travel
Which still makes up a complete gentleman,
Proves eminent in you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I must confess,
I have seen Jerusalem and Rome, have brought
Mark from th'one, from th'other testimony,
Know Spain, and France, and from their airs have sucked
A breath of every language: but no more
Of this discourse since we draw near the place
Of them we go to visit.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Noble master Geraldine, worshipful master Dalavill.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: I see thou still remember'st us.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Remember you, I have had so many memorandums from the multiplicities of your bounties, that not to remember you were to forget myself, you are both most ingeniously and nobly welcome.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: And why ingeniously and nobly?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Because had I given your welcomes other attributes than I have done, the one being a soldier, and the other seeming a scholar, I should have lied in the first, and showed myself a kind of blockhead in the last.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I see your wit is nimble as your tongue,
But how doth all at home?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Small doings at home sir, in regard that the age of my master corresponds not with the youth of my mistress, and you know cold January and lusty may seldom meet in conjunction.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: I do not think but this fellow in time may for his wit and understanding make almanacs?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Not so sir, you being more judicious than I, I'll give you the pre-eminence in that, because I see by proof you have such judgement in times and seasons.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.p: And why in times and seasons?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Because you have so seasonably made choice, to come so just at dinner time; you are welcome gentlemen, I'll go tell my master of your coming.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: A pleasant knave.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: This fellow I perceive
Is well acquainted with his master's mind,
O 'tis a good old man.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: And she a lady.
For beauty and for virtue unparalleled,
Nor can you name that thing to grace a woman
She has not in a full perfection,
Though in their years might seem disparity.
And therefore at the first, a match unfit;
Imagine but his age and government,
Withal, her modesty, and chaste respect;
Betwixt them, there's so sweet a sympathy,
As crowns a noble marriage.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis acknowledged,
But to the worthy gentleman himself,
I am so bound in many courtesies,
That not the least, by all th' expression
My labour, or my industry can show,
I will know how to cancel.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: O you are modest.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: He studies to engross me to himself,
And is so wedded to my company,
He makes me stranger to my father's house,
Although so near a neighbour.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: This approves you,
To be most nobly propertied, that from one
So exquisite in judgement, can attract
So affectionate an eye.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Your character,
I must bestow on his unmerited Jove,
As one that know I have it, and yet ignorant
Which way I should deserve it: here both come.

div.stage: Enter old Mr. Wincott, wife, Prudentilla the sister, and the clown.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Gentlemen, welcome, but what need I use
A word so common, unto such to whom
My house was never private; I expect
You should not look for such a needle's phrase,
Especially you master Geraldine,
Your father is my neighbour, and I know you,
Even from the cradle, than I loved your infancy,
And since your riper growth bettered by travel;
My wife and you, in youth were playfellows,
And nor now be strangers; as I take it,
Not above two years different in your age.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So much he hath out stripped me.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: I would have you
Think this your home, free as your father's house,
And to command it, as the master on 't;
call boldly here, and entertain your friends,
As in your own possessions, when I see't,
I'll say you love me truly, not till then;
O what a happiness your father hath,
Far above me, one to inherit after him,
Where I (Heaven knows) am childless.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: That defect
Heaven hath supplied in this your virtuous wife,
Both fair, and full of all accomplishments.
My father is a widower, and herein
Your happiness transcends him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O master Geraldine,
Flattery in men's an adjunct of their sex,
This country breeds it, and for that, so far
You needed not to have travelled.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Truth's a word,
That should in every language relish well,
Nor have I that exceeded.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, my husband
Hath taken much pleasure in your strange discourse
About Jerusalem and the holy land;
How the new city differs from the old,
What ruins of the temple yet remain,
And whether Zion, and those hills about,
With these adjacent towns and villages,
Keep that proportioned distance as we read;
And then in Rome, of that great pyramis
Reared in the front, on four lions mounted,
How many of those idol temples stand,
First dedicated to their heathen gods,
Which ruined, which to better use repaired,
Of their Pantheon, and their Capitol,
What structures are demolished, what remain.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: And what more pleasure to an old man's ear,
That never drew, save his own country's air,
Then hear such things related. I do exceed him
In years, I must confess, yet he much older
Than I in his experience.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Master Geraldine,
May I be bold to ask you but one question.
The which I'd be resolved in.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Any thing, that lies within my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Put him to't,
Do sister, you shall find him (Make no doubt)
Most pregnant in his answer.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: In your travels
Through France, through Savoy, and through Italy,
Spain, and the empire, Greece and Palestine,
Which breeds the choicest beauties.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Intruth lady,
I never cast on any in those parts
A curious eye of censure, since my travel
Was only aimed at language, and to know;
These passed me but as common objects did,
Seen, but not much regarded.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: O you strive
To express a most unheard of modesty,
And seldom found in any traveller,
Especially of our country, thereby seeking
To make yourself peculiar.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I should be loath
Profess in outward show to be one man,
And prove myself another.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: One thing more,
Were you to marry, you that know these climbs,
Their states and their conditions, out of which
Of all these countries would you choose your wife.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I'll answer you in brief, (As I observe)
Each several clime for object, fare, or use,
Affords within itself, for all of these
What is most pleasing to the man there born;
Spain, that yields scant of food, affords the nation
A parsimonious stomach, where our appetites
Are not content but with the large excess
Of a full table; where the pleasing'st fruits
Are found most frequent, there they best content;
Where plenty flows, it asks abundant feasts;
For so hath provident nature dealt with all;
So in the choice of women, the Greek wantoness
Comple'd beneath the Turkish slavery,
vassal themselves to all men, and such best
Please the voluptuous, that delight in change;
The French is of one humour, Spain another,
The hot Italian he's a strain from both,
All pleased with their own nations even the Moor,
He thinks the blackest the most beautiful;
And lady, since you so far tax my choice,
I'll thus resolve you; being an English man,
Amongst all these nations I have seen or tried,
To please me best, here would I choose my bride.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: And happy were that lady, in my thoughts,
Whom you would deign that grace too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: How now sister,
This is a fashion that's but late come up,
For maids to court their husbands.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: I would wife
It were no worse, upon condition,
They had my helping hand and purse to boot,
With both in ample measure; o this gentleman,
I love, nay almost dote on.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You've my leave,
To give it full expression.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: In these arms then,
O had my youth been blessed with such a son,
To have made my estate to my name hereditary,
I should have gone contented to my grave,
As to my bed; to death, as to my sleep;
But heaven hath will in all things, once more welcome,
And you sir, for your friend's sake.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Would I had in me,
That which he hath, to have claimed it for mine own,
However , I much thank you.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Now sir, the news with you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Dancing news sir,
For the meat stands piping hot upon the dresser,
The kitchen's in a heat and the cook hath so bestirred himself,
That he's in a sweat. The Jack plays music, and the spits
Turn round to't.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: This fellows my best clock,
He still strikes true to dinner.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And to supper too sir, I know not how the day goes with you, but my stomach hath struck twelve, I can assure you that.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: You take us unprovided gentlemen,
Yet something you shall find and we would rather
Give you the entertain of household guests,
Then compliment of strangers, I pray enter.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll stand to't, that in good hospitality, there can be nothing found that's ill, he that's a good housekeeper, keeps a good table, a good table, is never without good stools, good stools, seldom without good guests, good guests, never without good cheer, good cheer, cannot be without good stomachs, good stomachs, without good digestion, good digestion, keeps men in good health, and therefore all good people, that bear good minds, as you love goodness, be sure to keep good meat and drink in your houses, and so you shall be called good men, and nothing can come on't but good, I warrant you.

div.head: Actus primus. Scaena secundus.
div.stage: Enter two serving-men Reignald and Robin.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Away you Corridon.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Shall I be beaten out of my masters house thus?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Thy master, we are lords amongst ourselves,
And here we live and reign, two years already
Are past of our great empire, and we now
Write, anno tertio.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But the old man lives,
That shortly will depose you.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Ith' mean time,
I, as the mighty lord and seneschal
Of this great house and castle, banish thee,
The very smell ath' kitchen, be it death,
To appear before the dresser,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And why so?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Because thou stinkest of garlic, is that breath
Agreeing with our palace, where each room,
Smells with musk, civet, and rich ambergris,
Aloes, cassia, aromaticke-gummes,
Perfumes, and powders, one whose very garments
Scent of the fowls and stables, o fie, fie,
What a base nasty rogue 'tis.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yet your fellow.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Then let us put a carthorse in rich trappings.
And bring him to the tiltyard.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Prank it, do,
Waste, riot, and consume, misspend your hours
In drunken surfeits, lose your days in sleep,
And burn the nights in revels, drink and drab,
Keep Christmas all year long, and blot lean lent
Out of the calendar; all that mass of wealth
Got by my master's sweat and thirsty care,
Havoc in prodigal uses; make all fly,
Powr't down your oily throats, or send it smoking
Out at the tops of chimneys: at his departure,
Was it the old man's charge to have his windows
Glister all night with stars? his modest house
Turned to a common stews? his beds to palates
Of lusts and prostitutions? his buttery hatch
Now made more common than a tavern's bar,
His stools that welcomed none but civil guests,
Now only free for panders, whores and bawds,
Strumpets, and such.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I suffer thee too long,
What is to me thy country, or to thee
The pleasure of our city? thou hast cows,
Cattle, and beeves to feed, oues and boves,
These that I keep, and in this pasture graze,
Are dainty damosellas, bonny girls;
If thou beest born to hedge, ditch, thrash and plough
And I to revel, banquet and carouse;
Thou peasant, to the spade and pickaxe, I
The battoon and stiletto think it only
Thy ill, my good, our several lots are cast,
And both must be contented.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But when both our services are questioned.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Look thou to one,
My answer is provided.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Farewell musk-cat.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Adieu good cheese and onions, stuff thy guts
With speck and barley-pudding for digestion,
Drink whig and sour milk, whilst I rinse my throat,
With Bordeaux and Canary.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: What was he?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: A spy sir,
One of their hinds oth' country, that came prying
To see what dainty fare our kitchen yields,
What guests we harbour, and what rule we keep,
And threats to tell the old man when he comes;
I think I sent him packing.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: It was well done.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: A whoreson-jack-an-apes, a base baboon,
To insinuate in our secrets.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Let such keep, the country where their charge is.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: So I said sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: And visit us when we command them thence,
Not search into our counsels.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: 'Twere not fit.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Who in my father's absence should command,
Save I his only son?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: It is but justice.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: For am not I now lord?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Dominus fac totum.
And am not I your steward?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Well remembered,
This night I have a purpose to be merry,
Jovial and frolic, how doth our cash hold out?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: The bag's still heavy.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Then my heart's still light.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I can assure you, yet 'tis pretty deep,
Though scarce a mile to th' bottom.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Let me have
To supper, let me see, a duck —

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Sweet rogue.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: A capon —

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Geld the rascal.

sp.speaker: Young Lio.
sp.l: Then a Turkey —

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Now spit him for an infidel.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Greene plover, snite,
Partridge, lark, cock, and pheasant.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Ne'er a widgeon?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Yes, wait thyself at table.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Where I hope yourself will not be absent.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Nor my friends.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: We'll have them then in plenty.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Caviar, sturgeon, anchoves, pickle oysters: yes,
And a potato pie; besides all these,
What thou think'st rare and costly.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Sir, I know
What's to be done; the stock that must be spent,
Is in my hands, and what I have to do,
I will do suddenly.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: No butcher's meat,
Of that, beware in any case.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I still remember,
Your father was no grazier, if he were,
This were a way to eat up all his fields,
Hedges and all.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: You will be gone sir.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Yes, and you are ith' way going.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: To what may young men best compare themselves?
Better to what, than to a house new built?
The fabric strong, the chambers well contrived,
Polished within, without, well beautified;
When all that gaze upon the edifice,
Do not alone commend the workman's craft,
But either make it their fair precedent
By which to build another, or at least,
Wish there to inhabit: being set to sale,
In comes a slothful tenant, with a family
As lazy and debauched; rough tempests rise,
Untile the roof, which by their idleness,
Left unrepaired, the stormy showers beat in,
Rot the main posts and rafters, spoil the rooms,
Deface the seelings, and in little space,
Bring it to utter ruin, yet the fault,
Not in the architector that first reared it,
But him that should repair it: so it fares
With us young men; we are those houses made,
Our parents raise these structures, the foundation
Laid in our infancy; and as we grow
In years, they strive to build us by degrees,
Story on story higher; up at height,
They cover us with council, to defend us
From storms without: they polish us within,
with learnings, knowledge, arts and disciplines;
All that is naught and vicious, they sweep from us,
Like dust and cobwebs, and our rooms concealed,
Hang with the costliest hangings; bout the walls,
Emblems and beauteous symbols pictured round;
But when that lazy tenant, love, steps in,
And in his train, brings sloth and negligence,
Lust, disobedience, and profuse excess;
The thrift with which our fathers tiled our roofs,
Submits to every storm and winter's blast,
sp.stage: Enter Blanda a whore, and scapha a bawd.
sp.l: And yielding place to every riotous sin,
Gives way without, to ruin what's within:
Such is the state I stand in.

sp.speaker: Blan.
sp.l: And how doth this tire become me?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Rather ask, how your sweet carriage,
And court behaviour, doth best grace you, for lovers regard,
Not so much the outward habit, as that which the garment covers.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: O here's that hail, shower, tempest, storm, and gust,
That shattered hath this building; let in lust,
Intemperance appetite to vice; withal,
Neglect of every goodness; thus I see,
How I am sinking in mine own disease,
Yet can I not abide it.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: And how this gown? I prithee view me well,
And speak with thy best judgement.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: What do you talk of gowns, and ornaments;
That have a beauty, precious in itself,
And becomes any thing.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Let me not live, but she speaks naught but truth,
And I'll for that reward her.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: All's one to me, become they me, or not,
Or be I fair, or foul, in others eyes,
So I appear so to my Lionell,
He is the glass, in whom I judge my face,
By whom in order, I will dress these curls,
And place these jewels, only to please him,
Why dost smile.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: To here a woman, that thinks herself so wise, speak so foolishly, that knows well, and does ill.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Teach me wherein I err.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: I'll tell thee daughter; in that thou knowest thyself to be beloved of so many, and settlest thy affection, only upon one; doth the mill grind only, when the wind sits in one corner? Or ships only sail, when it's in this, or that quarter? Is he a cunning fencer, that lies but at one guard? Or he a skilful musician, that plays but on one string? Is there but one way to the wood? And but one bucket that belongs to the well? To affect one, and despise all other, becomes the precise matron, not the prostitute; the loyal wife, not the loose wanton: such have I been, as you are now, and should learn, to sail with all winds, defend all blows, make music with all strings, know all the ways, to the wood, and like a good travelling hackney, learn to drink of all waters.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: May I miscarry in my Blanda's love;
If I that old damnation, do not send
To hell, before her time.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I would not have you mother, teach me ought,
That tends to injure him.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: Well look to't when 'tis late, and then repent at leisure, as I have done; thou seest, here's nothing but prodigality and pride, wantoning, and wasting, rioting, and revelling, spoiling, and spending, gluttony, and gormandizing, all goes to havoc, and can this hold out? When he hath nothing left, to help himself, how can he harbour thee? Look at length, to drink from a dry bottle, and feed from an empty knapsack, look too 't, 'twill come to that.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: My parsimony shall begin in thee,
And instantly, for from this hour, I vow,
That thou no more shalt drink upon my cost,
Nor taste the smallest fragment from my board;
I'll see thee starve ith' street first.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: Live to one man? A jest, thou mayest as well, tie thyself to one gown; and what fool, but will change with the fashion, yes, do, confine thyself to one garment, and use no variety, and see how soon it will rot, and turn to rags.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Those rags, be thy reward; o my sweet Blanda,
Only for thee, I wish my father dead,
And ne'er to rouse us from our sweet delight;
But for this hag, this beldame, she whose back,
Hath made her items, in my mercer's books,
Whose raucous guts, I have stuffed with delicates,
nay even to surfeit; and whose frozen blood,
I have warmed with aquavitae; be this day
My last of bounty, to a wretch ingrate,
But unto thee, a new indenture scaled,
Of an affection fixed, and permanent,
I'll love thee still, be 't but to give the lie,
To this old cankered worm.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: With thee, my soul shall ever be at peace,
But with this love seducer, still at war.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Ope but thy lips again, it makes a way,
To have thy tongue plucked out.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: What all in tempest?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Yes, and the storm, raised by that witches spells.
O 'tis a damned enchantress.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: What's the business?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Only some few words, slipped her unawares,
For my sake, make her peace.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: You charge me deeply,
Come friend, will you be moved at women's words,
A man of your known judgement?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Had you but heard,
The damned erroneous doctrine that she taught,
You would have judged her to the stake.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: But sweet heart,
She now recants those errors, once more number her
Amongst your household servants.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Shall she beg, and be denied ought from you?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Come this kiss, shall end all former quarrels.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: 'Tis not possible,
Those lips should move in vain, that two ways plead;
Both in their speech, and silence.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: You have prevailed,
But upon this condition, no way else,
I'll censure her, as she hath sentenced thee;
But with some small inversion,

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Speak, how's that?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Not too severe, I prithee see poor wretch,
She at the bar, stands quaking.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Now, hold up?

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: How man, how?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Her hand, I mean; and now i'll sentence thee,
According to thy council given to her:
Sail by one wind; thou shalt, to one tune sing,
Lie at one guard, and play but on one string,
Henceforth, I will confine thee to one garment,
And that shall be a cast one, like thyself
Just, passed all wearing, as thou passed all use,
And not to be renewed, till't be as ragged,
As thou art rotten.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Nay sweet.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: That for her habit.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: A cold suit, I have on 't,

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: To prevent surfeit,
They diet, sha' I be to one dish confined,
And that too rifled, with as unclean hands,
As ere were laid on thee.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: What he scants me in victuals, would he but allow once in drink.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: That shall be the refuse of the flagons, jaoks,
And snuffs, such as the naftieft breathes shall leave;
Of wine, and strong-water, never hope,
Henceforth to smell.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: O me, I faint already.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: If I sink in my state, of all the rest,
Be thou excused, what thou proposed to her,
Beldame, is now against thyself decreed,
Drink from dry springs, from empty, knapsacks feed.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: No burned wine, nor hot-waters.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Take her hence.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Indeed you are too cruel.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Yes to her,
Only of purpose, to be kind to thee;
Are any of my guests come?

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Fear not sir,
You will have a fill table.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: What, and music?

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Best consort in the city, for fix parts.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: We shall have songs then?

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Byth'ear.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: And wenches?

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Yes byth'eyc.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Ha, what was that you said?

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: We shall have such to bear you company,
As will no doubt content you.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Enter then:
In youth there is a fate, that sways us still.
To know what's good, and yet pursue what's ill..

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter old master Wincott, and his wife.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: And what's this Dalavill?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My apprehension,
Can give him no more true expression,
Then that he first appears, a gentleman,
And well conditioned.

sp.speaker: Wino.
sp.l: That for outward show;
But what in him have you observed else,
To make him better known?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I have nor eyes,
To search into the inward thoughts of men,
Nor ever was studied in that art,
To judge of meus affection by the face;
But that which makes me best opinioned of him,
Is, that he's companion, and the friend
Beloved of him, whom you so much commend,
The noble master Geraldine,

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Thou hast spoke,
That which not only crowns his true desert,
But now instates him, in my better thoughts,
Making his worth, unquestioned.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He pretends
Love to my sister Pru. I have observed him,
Single her out, to private conference.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: But I could rather, for her own sake, wish
Young Geraldine would fix his thoughts that way,
And she towards him; in such affinity,
Trust me, I would not use a sparing hand.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: But love in these kinds, should not be compelled,
Forced, nor persuaded; when it freely springs,
And of itself, takes voluntary root,
It grows, it spreads, it ripens, and brings forth,
Such an usurious crop of timely fruit,
As crowns a plenteous autumn.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Such a harvest,
I should not be th' ungladdest man to see,
Of all thy sister's friends: now, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Who, I sir, from a lodging of largesse, a house of hospitality, and a palace of plenty; where there's feeding like horses, and drinking like fishes; where for pints, we're served in pottles; and in stead of pottle-pots, in pails; in stead of siluer-tanckards, we drink out of water-tanckards; claret runs as freely, as the cocks; and Canary, like the conduits of a coronation day; where there's nothing but feeding and frolicking; carving in kissing; drinking, and dancing; music and madding; fiddling and feasting.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: And where, I pray thee, are all these revels kept?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: They may be rather called reeks than revels; as I came along by the door, I was called up amongst them; hee-gallants, and shee-gallants, I no sooner looked out; but saw them out with their knives, slashing of shoulders, mangling of legs, and launching of loins, till there was scarce a whole limb lest amongst them.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: A fearful massacre.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: One was hacking to cut off a neck, this was mangling a breast, his knife slip from the shoulder, and only cut of a wing, one was picking the brains out of a head, another was knuckle deep in a belly, one was groping for a liver, another searching for the kidneys; I saw one pluck the sole from the body (Goose that she was to suffer't) another pricked into the breast with his one bill, woodcock to endure it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How fell they out at first?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I know not that, but it seems, one had a stomach, and another had a stomach; but there was such biting and tearing with their teeths, that I am sure, I saw some of their poor carcases pay for't.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Did they not send for surgeons?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Alas no, surgeons help was too late; there was no stitching up of those wounds, where limb was plucked from limb; nor any salve for those scars, which all the plaster of Paris cannot cure.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Where grew the quarrel first?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
It seems it was first broached in the kitchen; certain creatures being brought in thither, by some of the house; the cook being a choleric fellow, did so touse them and toss them, so pluck them and pull them, till he left them as naked as my nail, pinioned some of them like felons; cut the spurs from others of their
heels; then down went his spits, some of them he ran in at the throat, and out at the backside; about went his basting-ladle, where he did so besauce them, that many a shrewd turn they had amongst them.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But in all this, how did the women scape?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: They fared best, and did the least hurt that I saw; but for quietness' sake, were forced to swallow what is not yet digested, yet every one had their share, and she that had least, I am sure by this time, hath her belly full.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: And where was all this havoc kept?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Marry sir, at your next neighbours, young master Lionell, where there is nothing but drinking out of dry-fats, and healthing in halfe-tubs, his guests are fed by the belly, and beggars served at his gate in baskets; he's the adamant of this age, the daffodil of these days, the prince of prodigality, and the very Caesar of all young citizens.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: Belike then, 'twas a massacre of meat, not as I apprehended?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Your gravity hath guessed aright; the chiefest that fell in this battle, were wild fowl and tame fowl; pheasants were wounded in stead of Alfaresse, and capons for captains, anchoves stood for antiants, and caviar for corporals, dishes were assaulted in stead of ditches, and rabbits were cut to pieces upon the rebels, some lost their legs, whilst other of their wings were forced to fly; the pioneer undermined nothing but piecrust; and —

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Enough, enough, your wit hath played too long upon our patience;
Wife, it grieves me much both for the young and old man, the one,
Graces his head with care, endures the parching heat and biting cold,
The terrors of the lands, and fears at sea in travel, only to gain
Some competent estate to leave his son;
Whiles all that merchandise, through gulfs, crosse-tides,
Pirates and storms, he brings so far; th' other
Here shipwracks in the harbour.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis the care of fathers; and the weakness
Incident to youth, that wants experience.

div.stage: Enter Y. Geraldine, Dallavill, Prudentilla, laughing.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I was at the beginning of the battle,
But here comes some, that it seems
Were at the rifling of the dead carcases;
For by their mirth, they have had part of the spoil.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: You are pleasant, gentlemen, what i
Might be the subject of your pleasant sport,
It promiseth some pleasure?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: If their recreation
Be, as I make no question, on truth grounded,
'Twill beget sudden laughter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What's the project?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Who shall relate it.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Master Geraldine, if there be any thing can please my ear,
With pleasant sounds, your tongue must be the instrument,
On which the string must strike.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Be't his then.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Nay hear it, 'tis a good one.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: We entreat you, possess us oth' novel,

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Speak, good sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I shall then, with a kind of barbarism,
Shadow a jest, that asks a smoother tongue,
For in my poor discourse, I do protest,
'Twill but lose his luster.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: You are modest.

sp.speaker: Winc
sp.l: However speak, I pray; for my sake do't?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This is like a hasty pudding, longer in eating then it was in making.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Then thus it was, this gentleman and I,
Passed but just now, by your next neighbour's house,
Where as they say, dwells one young Lionell.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Where I was tonight at supper.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: An unthrift youth, his father now at sea.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Why that's they very subject, upon which
It seems, this jest is grounded, there this night,
Was a great feast.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Why so I told you, sir.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Be thou still dumb, 'tis he that I would hear.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: In the height of their carousing, all their brains,
Warmed with the heat of wine; discourse was offered,
Of ships, and storms at sea; when suddenly,
Out of his giddy wildness, one conceives
The room wherein they quaffed, to be a pinnace,
Moving and floating; and the confused noise,
To be the murmuring winds, gusts, mariners;
That their unsteadfast footing, did proceed
from rocking of the vessel: this conceived,
Each one begins to apprehend the danger,
And to look out for safety, fly saith one
Up to the manne-top, and discoverer; he
Climbs by the bed post, to the taster, there
Reports a turbulent sea and tempest towards;
And wills them if they'll save their ship and lines,
To cast their lading overboard; at this
All fall to work, and hoist into the street,
As to the sea, what next come to their hand,
Stools, tables, trestles, trenchers, bedsteads, cups,
Pots, plate, and glasses; here a fellow whistles,
They take him for the boatswain, one lies struggling
Upon the floor, as if he swum for life,
A third, takes the bass-viol for the cockboat,
Sits in the belly on't, labours and rows;
His oar, the stick with which the fiddler played;
A fourth, bestrides his fellows, thinking to scape
As did Arion, on the dolphin's back,
Still fumbling on a gittern.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: But what was the conclusion?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: The rude multitude,
Watching without, and gaping for the spoil
Cast from the windows, went byth'ears about it;
The constable is called to atone the broil,
Which done, and hearing such a noise within,
Of eminent shipwreck; enters the house, and finds them
In this confusion, they adore his staff,
And think it Neptune's trident, and that he
Comes with his Tritons, (So they called his watch)
To calm the tempest, and appease the waves;
And at this point, we left them.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Come what will, I'll steal out of doors,
And see the end of it, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Thanks master Geraldine, for this discourse,
Intruth it hath much pleased me, but the night
Begins to grow fast on us, for your parts,
You are all young, and you may sit up late,
My eyes begin to summon me to sleep,
and nothing's more offensive unto age,
Then to watch long and late.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Now good rest with you.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: What says fair Prudentilla? Maids and widows,
And we young bachelors, such as indeed
Are forced to lie in solitary beds,
And sleep without disturbance; we methinks,
Should desire later hours; when married wines,
That in their amorous arms, hug their delights;
To often wakings subject; their more haste,
May better be excused.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: How can you,
That are as you confess, a single man,
Enter so far into these mystical secrets
Of marriage, which as yet you never proved.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: There's lady, an instinct innate in man,
Which prompts us to the apprehensions
Of th' uses we were born to; such we are
Aptest to learn; ambitious most to know,
Of which our chief is marriage.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: What you men
Most meditate, we women seldom dream of.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: When dream maids most?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: When think you?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: When you lie upon your backs, come come, your ear.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: We now are left alone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why say we be who should be jealous of us?
This is not first of many hundred nights,
That we two have been private, from the first
Of our acquaintance, when our tongues but clipped
Our mother's-tongue, and could not speak it plain,
We knew each other; as in slatnre, so
Increased our sweet society; since your travel,
And my late marriage, through my husband's love,
Midnight hath been as midday, and my bedchamber,
As free to you, as your own father's house,
And you as welcome too 't.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I must confess,
It is in you, your noble courtesy,
In him, a more than common confidence,
And in this age, can scarce find precedent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Most true, it is withal an argument,
That both our virtues are so deep impressed
In his good thoughts, he knows we cannot err.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: A villain were he, to deceive such trust,
Or (Were there one) a much worse character.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And she no less, whom either beauty, youth,
Time, place, or opportunity could tempt,
To injure such a husband.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: You deserve, even for his sake, to be for ever young;
And he for yours, to have his youth renewed;
So mutual is your true conjugal love; yet had the fates so pleased

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I know your meaning,
It was once voiced, that we two should have matched,
The world so thought, and many tongues so spoke,
But heaven hath now disposed us otherways;
And being as it is, (A thing in me,
Which I protest, was never wished, nor sought)
Now done, I not repent it.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: In those times,
Of all the treasures of my hopes and love,
You were th' exchequer, they were stored in you;
And had not my unfortunate travel crossed them,
They had been here reserved still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Troth they had,
I should have been your trusty treasurer.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: However let us love still, I entreat:
That, neighbourhood and breeding will allow;
So much the laws divine and human both,
Twixt brother and a sister will approve;
Heaven then forbid, that they should limit us
Wish well to one another.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: If they should not,
We might proclaim, they were not charitable,
Which were a deadly fin but to conceive.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Will you resolve me one thing?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: As to one, that in my bosom hath a second place, next my dear husband.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: That's the thing I crave,
And only that, to have a place next him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Presume on that already, but perhaps,
you mean to stretch it further.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Only thus far,
Your husband's old, to whom my soul doth wish,
A Nester's age, so much he merits from me;
Yet if (As proof and nature daily teach)
Men cannot always live, especially
Such as are old and crazed; he be called hence,
Fairly, in full maturity of time,
And we two be reserved to after life,
Will you confer your widowhood on me?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You ask the thing, I was about to beg;
Your tongue hath spoken mine own thoughts.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Vow to that.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: As I hope mercy.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis enough, that word
Alone, instates me happy; now so please you,
We will divide, you to your private chamber,
I to find out my friend.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Nay master Geraldine, one ceremony rests yet unperformed,
My vow is past, your oath must next proceed,
And as you covet to be sure of me,
Of you I would be certain.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Make ye doubt?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No doubt; but love's still jealous, and in that
To be excused; you then shall swear by heaven,
And as in all your future acts, you hope
To thrive and prosper; as the day may yield
Comfort, or the night rest, as you would keep
Entire, the honour of your father's house,
And free your name from scandal and reproach,
By all the goodness that you hope to enjoy,
Or ill to shun —

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: You charge me deeply lady.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Till that day come, you shall reserve yourself
A single man; converse nor company
With any woman, contract nor combine,
With maid, or widow; which expected hour,
As I do wish not haste, so when it happens,
It shall not come unwelcome; you here all, vow this.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: By all that you have said, I swear, and by this kiss confirm.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You're now my brother,
But then, my second husband.

div.stage: Enter Y. Lionell, rioter, Blanda, scapha, two gallants, and two wenches, as newly waked from sleep.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: We had a stormy night on't.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: The wine still works,
And with the little rest they have taken tonight ,
They are scarce come to themselves.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Now 'tis a calm,
Thanks to those gentle seagods, that have brought us
To this safe harbour; can you tell their names?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: He with the painted-staff, I heard you call Neptune.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: The dreadful god of seas,
Upon whose back near stuck march flees.

sp.speaker: 1. Gall.
sp.l: One with the bill, keeps Neptune's porpoises,
So Ovid says in's metamorphosis.

sp.speaker: 2. Gall.
sp.l: A third the learned poets write on,
And as they say, his name is Triton.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: These are the marine gods, to whom my father
In his long voyage prays too; cannot they
That brought us to our haven, bury him
In their abyss? For if he safe arrive,
I with these sailors, Syrens, and what not,
Am sure here to be shipwrecked.

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.l: Stand up stiff.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: But that the ship so totters: I shall fall.

sp.speaker: 1. Wen.
sp.l: If thou fall, I'll fall with thee.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Now I sink,
And as I dive and drown, thus by degrees,
I'll pluck thee to the bottom.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: A main for England, see, see,
The Spaniard now strikes sail.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: So must you all.

sp.speaker: 1. Gall.
sp.l: Whence is your ship, from the Bermoothes?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Worse, I think from hell:
We are all lost, split, shipwrecked, and undone,
This place is a mere quicksands.

sp.speaker: 2. Gall.
sp.l: So we feared.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Where's my young master?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Here man, speak, the news?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: The news is, I, and you —

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: She, and all these —

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: We, and all ours, are in one turbulent sea
Of fear, despair, disaster and mischance swallowed:
Your father, sir —

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Why, what of him?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: He is, o I want breath.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Landed, and at hand.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Upon what coast? Who saw him?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Ay, these eyes.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: O heaven, what shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Ask ye me what shall become of you, that have not yet
Had time of study to dispose myself;
I say again, I was upon the key,
I saw him land, and this way bend his course;
What drunkard's this, that can out sleep a storm
Which threatens all our ruins? Wake him.

sp.speaker: Ela.
sp.l: Ho, rioter, awake.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Yes, I am wake;
How dry hath this salt-water made me; boy,
Give me th' other glass.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Arise, I say,
My fathers come from sea.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: If he be come, bid him be gone again.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Can you trifle at such a time, when your inventions.
Brains, wits, plots, devices, stratagems, and all
Should be at one in action? each of you
That love your safeties, lend your helping hands,
Women and all, to take this drunkard hence,
And to bestow him else where.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Lift for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: But what am I the nearer, were all these
Conveyed to sundry places and unseen;
The stain of our disorders still remain,
Of which, the house will witness, and the old man
Must find when he enters; and for these
I am here left to answer: what is he gone?

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: But whither? But into th' self same house
That harbours him; my fathers, where we all
Attend from him surpriseall.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I will make
That prison of your fears, your sanctuary;
Go get you in together.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: To this house?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Your fathers, with your sweetheart, these and all;
Nay, no more words but do't,

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: That were to betray us to his fury.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I have't here,
To bail you hence at pleasure; and in th' interim,
I'll make this supposed goal, to you, as safe
From th' injured old man's just incensed spleen,
As were you now together ith' Low-countreyes,
Virginia, or ith' Indies.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Present fear,
Bids us to yield unto the faint belief
Of the least hoped safety.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Will you in?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: By thee we will be counselled.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Shut them fast.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: And thou and I to leave them?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: No such thing, for you shall bear your sweetheart company, and help to cheer the rest.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: And so thou
Meanest to escape alone?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Rather without,
I'll stand a champion for you all within;
Will you be swayed? One thing in any case
I must advise; the gates bolted and locked,
See that amongst you no living voice be heard;
No not so much as a dog to howl,
Or cat to mew, all silence, that I charge;
As if this were a mere forsaken house,
And none did there inhabit.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: And though the old man thunder at the gates
As if he meant to ruin what he had reared,
None on their lives to answer.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: 'Tis my charge;
Remains there nothing else?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Only the key; for I must play the gaoler for your durance, to be the Mercury in your release.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Me and my hope, I in this key deliver
To thy safe trust.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: When you are fast you are safe,
And with this turn 'tis done: what fools are these,
To trust their ruined fortunes to his hands
That hath betrayed his own; and make themselves
Prisoner to one deserves to lie for all,
As being cause of all; and yet something prompts me,
I'll stand it at all dangers; and to recompense
the many wrongs unto the young man done:
Now, if I can doubly delude the old,
My brain, about it then; all's hushed within,
The noise that shall be, I must make without;
And he that part for gain, and part for wit,
So far hath travelled, strive to fool at home:
Which to effect, art must with knavery join,
And smooth dissembling meet with impudence;
He do my best, and howsoe'er it prove,
My praise or shame, 'tis but a servant's love.

div.stage: Enter old Lionell like a civil merchant, with watermen, and two servants with burdens and caskets.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Discharge these honest sailors that have brought
Our chests ashore, and pray them have a care,
Those merchandise be safe we left aboard:
As heaven hath blessed us with a fortunate voyage,
In which we bring home riches with our healths,
So let not us prove niggards in our store;
See them paid well, and to their full content.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Then return: these special things,
And of most value, we'll not trust aboard;
Methinks they are not safe till they see home,
And there repose, where we will rest ourselves,
And bid farewell to travel; for I vow,
After this hour, no more to trust the seas,
Nor throw me to such danger.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I could wish
You had taken your leave oth' land too.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: And now it much rejoiceth me, to think
What a most sudden welcome I shall bring,
Both to my friends and private family.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: O, but how much more welcome had he been,
That had brought certain tidings of thy death.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But soft, what's this? my own gates shut upon me,
And bar their master entrance? Who's within there?
How, no man speak, are all asleep or dead,
That no soul stirs to open?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: What mad man's that, who weary of his life,
Dares once lay hand on these accursed gates?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Who's that? my servant Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: My old master,
Most glad I am to see you; are you well sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Thou seest I am.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: But are you sure you are?
Feel you no change about you? Pray you stand off.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What strange and unexpected greetings this,
That thus a man may knock at his own gates,
Beat with his hands and feet, and call thus loud,
And no man give him entrance?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Said you sir;
Did your hand touch that hammer?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Why, whose else?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: But are you sure you touched it?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: How else, I prithee, could I have made this noise?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: You touched it then?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: I tell thee yet I did.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: O for the love I bear you,
O me most miserable, you, for you own sake,
Of all alive most wretched; did you touch it?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Why, say I did?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: You have then a sin committed,
No sacrifice can expiate to the dead;
But yet I hope you did not.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: 'Tis past hope,
The deed is done, and I repent it not.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: You and all yours will do't. In this one rashness,
You have undone us all; pray be not desperate,
But first thank heaven that you have escaped thus well;
Come from the gate, yet further, further yet,
And tempt your fate no more; command your servants
Give off and come no nearer, they are ignorant,
And do not know the danger, therefore pity
That they should perish in 't; 'tis full seven months,
Since any of your house durst once set foot
Over that threshold.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Prithee speak the cause?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: First look about, beware that no man hear,
Command these to remove.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Be gone. Exit servants.now speak.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: O sir, this house is grown prodigious,
Fatal, disastrous unto you and yours.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.l: What fatal? what disastrous?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Some host that hath been owner of this house,
In it his guest hath slain; and we suspect
'Twas he of whom you bought it.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: How came this
Discovered to you first?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I'll tell you sir,
But further from the gate: your son one night
Supped late abroad, I within; o that night,
I never shall forget; being safe got home,
I saw him in his chamber laid to rest;
And after went to mine, and being drowsy,
Forgotten by chance, to put the candle out;
Being dead asleep; your son affrighted, calls
So loud, that I soon wakened; brought in light,
And found him almost drowned in fearful sweat;
Amazed to see't, I did demand the cause:
Who told me, that this murdered ghost appeared,
His body gashed, and all o'er-stuck with wounds;
And spoke to him as follows.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: O proceed, 'tis that I long to hear.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I am, quoth he,
A transmarine by birth, who came well stored
With gold and jewels, to this fatal house;
Where seeking safety, I encountered death:
The covetous merchant, landlord of this rent,
To whom I gave my life and wealth in charge;
Freely to enjoy the one, robbed me of both:
Here was my body buried, here my ghost
Must ever walk, till that have Christian right;
Till when, my habitation must be here:
Then fly young man, remove thy family,
And seek some safer dwelling: for my death,
This mansion is accursed; 'tis my possession,
Bought at the dear rate of my life and blood,
None enter here, that aims at his own good.
And with this charge he vanished.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: O my fear,
Whither wilt thou transport me?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I entreat keep further from the gate, and fly.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Fly whither? Why dost not thou fly too?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: What need I fear, the ghost and I am friends.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Tush, I nothing have deserved,
Nor ought transgressed: I came not near the gate.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: To whom was that thou spak'st?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Was't you sir named me?
Now as I live, I thought the dead man called,
To inquire for him that thundered at the gate
Which he so dear paid for: are you mad,
To stand a foreseen danger?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Cover you head and fly; lest looking back,
You spy your own confusion.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Why dost not thou fly too?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I tell you sir,
The ghost and I am friends.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Why didst thou quake then?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: In fear lest some mischance may fall on you,
That have the dead offended, for my part,
The ghost and I am friends: why fly you not,
Since here you are not safe?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Some blessed powers guard me.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Nay sir, I'll not forsake you: I have got the start;
But eat the goal, 'twill ask both brain and art.

div.head: Seena prima.
div.stage: Enter old master Geraldine, Y. Geraldine, master Wincott, and wife, Dalavill, Prudentilla.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: We are bound to you, kind master Geraldine,
For this great entertainment; troth your cost
Hath much exceeded common neighbourhood:
You have feasted us like princes.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: This, and more
Many degrees, can never countervail
The oft and frequent welcomes given my son:
You have taken him from me quite, and have I think,
Adopted him into your family,
He stays with me so seldom.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And in this,
By trusting him to me, of whom yourself
may have both use and pleasure, you're as kind
As moneyed men, that might make benefit
Of what they are possessed, yet to their friends
In need, will lend it gratis.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And like such,
As are indebted more than they can pay;
We more and more confess ourselves engaged
To you, for your forbearance.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Yet you see,
Like debtors, such as would not break their day;
The treasure late received, we tender back,
The which, the longer you can spare, you still
The more shall bind us to you.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Most kind ladies,
Worthy you are to borrow, that return
The principal, with such large use of thanks.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: What strange felicity these rich men take,
To talk of borrowing, lending, and of use;
The usurer's language right.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: You've master Geraldine,
Fair walks and gardens, I have praised them,
Both to my wife and sister.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: You would see them,
There's no pleasure that the house can yield,
That can be debarred from you; prithee son,
Be thou the usher to those mounts and prospects
May one day call thee master.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Sir I shall; please you to walk.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: What master Dalavill,
Will you not bear us company.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: 'Tis not fit
That we should leave our noble host alone,
Be you my friends charge, and this old man mine.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Well, be't then at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: You to your prospects, but there's project here
That's of another nature; worthy sir,
I cannot but approve your happiness,
To be the father of so brave a son,
So every way accomplished and made up,
in which my voice is least; for I alas,
Bear but a mean part in the common quire,
When with much louder accents of his praise,
So all the world reports him.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Thank my stars,
They have lent me one, who as he always was,
And is my present joy; if their aspect
Be no ways to our goods malevolent,
May be my future comfort.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Yet must I hold him happy above others,
As one that solely to himself enjoys
What many others aim at; but in vain.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: How mean you that?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: So beautiful a mistress.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: A mistress, said you?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Yes sir, or a friend,
Whether you please to style her.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Mistress? Friend?
Pray be more open languaged.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: And indeed,
Who can blame him to absent himself from home,
And make his father's house but as a grange,
For a beauty so attractive? Or blame her,
Hugging so weak an old man in her arms,
To make a new choice, of an equal youth,
Being in him so perfect? yet intruth,
I think they both are honest.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: You have sir,
Possessed me with such strange fancies.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: For my part,
How can I love the person of your son,
And not his reputation? His repair
So often to the house, is voiced by all,
And frequent in the mouths of the whole country,
Some equally addicted, praise his happiness;
But others, more censorious and austere,
Blame and reprove a course so dissolute;
Each one in general, pity the good man,
As one unfriendly dealt with, yet in my conscience,
I think them truly honest.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: 'Tis suspicious.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: True sir, at best; but what when scandalous tongues
will make the worst? and what good in itself,
Sully and stain by fabulous misreport;
For let men live as chary as they can,
Their lives are often questioned, then no wonder,
If such as give occasion of suspicion,
Be subject to this scandal: what I speak,
Is as a noble friend unto your son;
And therefore, as I glory in his fame,
I suffer in his wrong; for as I live,
I think, they both are honest.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Howsoever, I wish them so.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Some course might be devised,
To stop this clamour ere it grow too rank;
Lest that which yet but inconvenience seems,
May turn to greater mischief; this I speak
In zeal to both, in sovereign care of him
As of a friend; and tender of her honour,
As one to whom I hope to be allied,
By marriage with her sister.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: I much thank you,
For you have clearly given me light of that,
Till now I never dreamt on.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: 'Tis my love,
And therefore I entreat you, make not me
To be the first reporter.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: You have done
The office of a noble gentleman,
And shall not be so injured.

div.stage: Enter again as from walking Winc. wife, Y. Ger. Prud.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: See master Geraldine,
How bold we are, especially these ladies
Play little better than the thieves with you,
For they have robbed your garden.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You might sir,
Better have termed it sauciness, than theft;
You see we blush not, what we took in private,
To wear in public view.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Besides, these cannot
Be missed out of so many; in full fields,
The gleanings are allowed.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: These and the rest,
Are ladies, at your service.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Now to horse,
But one thing ere we part, I must entreat;
In which my wife will be joint suitor with me,
My sister too.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: In what I pray.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: That he
Which brought us hither, may but bring us home;
Your much respected son.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: How men are born,
To woe their own disasters?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But to see us
From whence he brought us sir, that's all.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: This second motion makes it palpable:
To note a woman's cunning; make her husband
Bawd to her own lascivious appetite,
And to solicit his own shame.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Nay sir,
When all of us join in so small a suit,
It were some injury to be denied.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: And work her sister too; what will not woman
To accomplish her own ends: but this disease,
I'll seek to physic ere it grow too far:
I am most sorry to be urged sweet friends,
In what at this time I can no ways grant;
Most, that these ladies should be ought denied,
To whom I owe all service, but occasions
Of weighty and important consequence,
Such as concern the best of my estate,
Call him aside; excuse us both this once,
Presume this business is no sooner over,
But he's at his own freedom.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: 'Twere no manners
In us to urge it further, we will leave you,
With promise sir, that he shall in my will,
Not be the last remembered.

sp.speaker: Old. Ger.
sp.l: We are bound to you;
See them to horse, and instantly return,
We have employments for you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Sir I shall,

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Remember your last promise,

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Not to do't, I should forget myself:
If I find him false
To such a friend, be sure he forfeits me;
In which to be more punctually resolved,
I have a project how to fifth his foul,
How 'tis inclined; whether to yonder place,
The clear bright palace, or black dungeon: see,
They are onward on the way, and he returned.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I now attend your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: You are grown perfect man, and now you float
Like to a well built vessel; between two currents,
Virtue and vice; take this, you steer to harbour;
Take that, to eminent shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Pray your meaning.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: What fathers cares are, you shall never know,
Till you yourself have children; now my study,
Is how to make you such, that you in them
May have a feeling of my love to you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Pray sir expound yourself, for I protest
Of all the languages I yet have learned,
This is to me most foreign.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Then I shall;
I have lived to see you in your prime of youth
And height of fortune, so you will but take
Occasion by the forehead; to be brief,
And cut off all superfluous circumstance,
All the ambition that I aim at now,
Is but to see you married.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Married sir.

sp.speaker: Old. Ger.
sp.l: And to that purpose, I have found out one,
Whose youth and beauty may not only please
A curious eye; but her immediate means,
Able to strengthen a state competent,
Or raise a ruined fortune.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Of all which,
I have believe me, neither need nor use;
My competence best pleasing as it is;
And this my singularity of life,
Most to my mind contenting.

sp.speaker: Odd Ger.
sp.l: I suspect, but yet must prove him further;
Say to my care I add a father's charge,
and couple with my counsel my command:
To that how can you answer?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: That I hope:
My duty and obedience still unblamed,
Did never merit such austerity;
And from a father never yet displeased.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Nay, than to come more near unto the point,
Either you must resolve for present marriage,
Or forfeit all your interest in my love.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Unsay that language, I entreat you sir,
And do not so oppress me; or if needs
Your heavy imposition stand in force,
Resolve me by your counsel; with more safety
May I infringe a sacred vow to heaven,
Or to oppose me to your strict command?
Since one of these I must.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Now Dalavill,
I find thy words too true.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: For marry, sir, I neither may, nor can.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Yet whore you may;
And that's no breach of any vow to heaven:
Pollute the nuptial bed with Michall sin;
Asperse the honour of a noble friend;
Forfeit thy reputation, here below.
And th' interest that thy soul might claim above,
In you blessed city: these you may, and can,
With untouched conscience: o, that I should live
To see the hopes that I have stored so long;
Thus in a moment ruined: and the staff,
On which my old decrepit age should lean;
Before my face thus broken: on which trusting,
I thus abortively, before my time,
Fall headlong to my grave.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: It yet stands strong;
Both to support you unto future life,
And fairer comfort.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Never, never son:
For till thou canst acquit thyself of scandal,
And me of my suspicion; here, even here,
Where I have measured out my length of earth;
I shall expire my last.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Both these I can:
Then rise sir, I entreat you; and that innocency,
Which poisoned by the breath of calumny, cast you thus low,
Shall, these few stains wiped off, with better thoughts erect you.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Well, say on.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: There's but one fire from which this smoke may grow;
Namely, the unmatched yoke of youth; and
In which, if ever I occasion was,
Of the smallest breach; the greatest implacable mischief
Adultery can threaten, fall on me;
Of you may I be disavowed a son;
And unto heaven a servant: for that lady,
As she is beauty's mirror, so I hold her
For chastities examples: from her tongue,
Never came language, that arrived my ear,
That even censorious Cato, lived he now,
Could misinterpret; never from her lips,
Came unchaste kiss; or from her constant eye,
Look savouring of the least immodesty: further —

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: Enough; one only thing remains, which on thy part performed, assures firm credit to these thy protestations.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Name it then.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Take hence th' occasion of this common fame;
Which hath already spread itself so far,
To her dishonour and thy prejudice, from this day forward,
To forbear the house: this do upon my blessing.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: As I hope it, I will not fail your charge.

sp.speaker: Old. Ger.
sp.l: I am satisfied.

div.stage: Enter at one door an usurer and his man, at the other, old Lionell with his servant: in the midst Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: To which hand shall I turn me; here's my master
Hath been to inquire of him that should the house,
Touching the murder; here's an usuring-rascal,
Of whom we have borrowed money to supply
Our prodigal expenses; broke our day,
And owe him still the principal and use:
Were I to meet them single, I have brain
To oppose both, and to come off unscarred;
But if they do assault me, and at once.
Not Hercules himself could stand that odds:
therefore I must encounter them by turns;
And to my master first: o sir, well met.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What Reignald; I but now met with the man,
Of whom I bought you house.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: What, did you sir?
But did you speak of ought concerning that
Which I last told you?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Yes, I told him all.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Then am I cast: but I pray tell me sir,
Did he confess the murder?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: No such thing; most stiffly he denies it.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Impudent wretch; then serve him with a warrant, let the officer
Bring him before a justice, you shall hear
What I can say against him; 'sfoot deny't:
But I pray sir excuse me, yonder's one
With whom I have some business; stay you here,
And but determine what's best course to take,
And note how I will follow't.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Be brief then.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Now, if I can as well put off my use-man,
This day, I shall be master of the field.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: That should be Lionel's man.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: The same, I know him.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: After so many frivolous delays,
There's now some hope. He that was wont to shun us,
And to absent himself, accosts us freely;
And with a pleasant countenance: well met Reignald,
What's this money ready?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Never could you
Have come in better time.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.p: Where's your master, young Lionell, it something troubles me, that he should break his day.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: A word in private,

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: Tush, private me no privates, in a word,
Speak, are my moneys ready?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Not so loud.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: I will be louder yet; give me my moneys,
Come, tender me my moneys.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: We know you have a throat, wide as your conscience; you need not use it now — come, get you home.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: Home?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Yes, home I say, return by three o'clock ,
And I will see all cancelled.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: 'Tis not passed two, and I can stay till three,
I'll make that now my business, otherways,
With these loud clamours, I will haunt thee still;
Give me my use, give me my principal.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: This burr will still cleave to me; what, no means
To shake him off; I near was caught till now.
Come come, you're trouble 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: Prevent that trouble,
And without trifling, pay me down my cash;
I will be fooled no longer.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: So so so.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: I have been still put off, from time to time,
And day today; these are but cheating tricks,
And this is the last minute I'll forbear
Thee, or thy master: once again, I say,
Give me my use, give me my principal.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Pox a this use, that hath and one so many:
And now will confound me.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Hast thou heard this?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes sir, and to my grief.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Come hither Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Here sir; nay, now I am gone.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What use is this?
What principal he talks of? in which language
He names my son; and thus upbraideth thee,
What is't you owe this man?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: A trifle sir,
Pray stop his mouth; and pay't him.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: I pay, what?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: If I say pay't him; pay't him.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What's the sum?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: A toy, the main about five hundred pounds;
And the use fifty.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Call you that a toy?
To what use was it borrowed? At my departure,
I left my son sufficient in his charge,
With surplus, to defray a large expense,
Without this need of borrowing.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: 'Tis confessed,
Yet stop his clamorous mouth; and only say,
That you will pay't tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: I pass my word.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Sir, if I bid you do't; nay, no more words,
But say you'll pay't tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Jest indeed, but tell me how these moneys were bestowed?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Safe sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: The sum still safe,
Why do you not then tender it yourselves?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Your ear sir; this sum joined to the rest,
Your son hath purchased land and houses.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Land, dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: A goodly house, and gardens.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Now joy on him,
That whilst his father merchandised abroad,
Had care to add to his estate at home:
But Reignald, wherefore houses?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Now lord sir,
How dull you are; this house possessed with spirits,
And there no longer stay; would you have had
Him, us, and all your other family,
To live, and lie ith' streets; it had not sir,
Been for your reputation.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Blessing on him,
That he is grown so thrifty.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: 'Tis struck three,
My money's not yet tendered.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Pox upon him,
See him discharged, I pray sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Call upon me
Tomorrow friend, as early as thou wilt;
I'll see thy debt defrayed.

sp.speaker: Vsu.
sp.l: It is enough, I have a true man's word.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Now tell me Reignald,
For thou hast made me proud of my son's thrift;
Where, in what country, doth this fair house stand.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Never in all my time, so much to seek;
I know not what to answer.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Wherefore studiest thou?
Use men to purchase lands at a dear rate,
And know not where they lie?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: 'Tis not for that,
I only had forgotten his name that should them,
'Twas let me see, see.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Call thyself to mind.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Nonplussed or never now; where art thou brain?
O sir, where was my memory; 'tis this house
That next adjoins to yours,

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: My neighbour Ricots.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: The same, the same sir; we had pennyworths in't;
And I can tell you, have been offered well
Since, to forsake our bargain.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: As I live,
I much commend your choice.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis well seated,
Roughcast without, but bravely lined within;
You have met with few such bargains.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Prithee knock,
And call the master, or the servant on't;
To let me take free view on't.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Puzzle again on puzzle; one word sir,
The house is full of women, no man knows,
How on the instant, they may be employed;
The rooms may lie unhandsome; and maids stand
Much on their cleanliness and housewifry;
To take them unprovided, were disgrace,
'Twere fit they had some warning; now, do you
Fetch but a warrant, from the justice sir;
You understand me.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: To attach him of suspected murder; I'll see't screwed;
Did he deny't? And in the interim, I
Will give them notice, you are now arrived,
And long to see your purchase.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Counselled well; and meet some half hour hence.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: This plunge well past,
All things fall even, to crown my brain at last.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Where shall we dine today?

sp.speaker: Dal
sp.l: At th' ordinary.
I see sir, you are but a stranger here;
this Barnet, is a place of great resort;
And commonly upon the market days,
Here all the country gentlemen appoint,
A friendly meeting; some about affairs
Of consequence and profit; bargain, sale,
And to confer with chapmen, some for pleasure,
To match their horses; wager in their dogs,
Or try their hawks; some to no other end,
But only meet good company, discourse,
Dine, drink, and spend their money.

div.stage: Enter old Geraldine and young Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: That's the market, we have to make this day.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: 'Tis a commodity, that will be easily vented:
What my worthy friend,
You are happily encountered; o, you're grown strange,
To one that much respects you; troth the house
Hath all this time seemed naked without you;
The good old man doth never sit to meat,
But next his giving thanks, he speaks of you;
There's scarce a bit, that he at table tastes,
That can digest without a Geraldine,
You are in his mouth so frequent: he and she
Both wondering, what distaste from one, or either,
So suddenly, should alienate a guest,
To them, so dear welcome.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Master Dalavill,
Thus much let me for him apology;
