Divers designs have thronged upon us late,
My weakness was not able to support
Without his help; he hath been much abroad,
At London, or else where; besides 'tis term;
And lawyers must be followed, seldom at home,
And scarcely then at leisure.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: I am satisfied,
And I would they were so too, but I hope sir,
In this restraint, you have not used my name.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Not, as I live.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: You're noble — who had thought
To have met with such good company; you're it seem
But new alighted; father and son, ere part,
I vow we'll drink a cup of sack together:
Physicians say, it doth prepare the appetite
And stomach against dinner.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: We old men,
Are apt to take these courtesies.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: What say you friend?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Lie but inquire for one, at the next inn,
And instantly return.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: 'Tis enough.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Bess: how dost thou gentle?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Faith we may do how we list for you, you are grown so great a stranger: we are more beholding
sp.l: To master Dalavill, he's a constant guest:
And howsoe'er to some, that shall be nameless,
His presence may be graceful; yet to others —
I could say somewhat.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: He's a noble fellow,
And my choice friend.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: Come come, he is, what he is; and that the end will prove.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: And how's all at home?
Nay, we'll not part without a glass of wine,
And meet so seldom: boy,
Drawer anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: A pint of claret, quickly.
Nay, sit down: the news, the news, I pray thee;
I am sure, I have been much enquired of
Thy old master, and thy young mistress too.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Ever your name is in my master's mouth, and sometimes too in hers, when she hath nothing else to think of:
sp.l: Well well, I could say somewhat.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Here's your wine sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Fill boy: here Bess, this glass to both their healths; why dost weep my wench?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: Nay, nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Come, I must know.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: Intruth I love you sir,
And ever wished you well; you are a gentleman,
Whom always I respected; know the passages
And private whisperings, of the secret love
Betwixt you and my mistress; I dare swear,
On your part well intended: but —

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: You bear the name of landlord, but another
enjoys the rent; you dote upon the shadow,
But another he bears away the substance.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Be more plain.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: You hope to enjoy a virtuous widowhood;
But Dalavill, whom you esteem you friend,
He keeps the wife in common.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: You're too blame,
And Bess, you make me angry; he's my friend,
And she my second self; in all their meetings,
I never saw so much as cast of eye
Once entertained betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: That's their cunning.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: For her; I have been with her at all hours,
Both late and early; in her bedchamber.
And often singly ushered her abroad:
Now, would she have been any man's alive,
She had been mine; you wrong a worthy friend,
And a chaste mistress, you're not a good girl;
Drink that speak better of her, I could chide you,
But I'll forbear; what you have rashly spoke,
Shall ever here be buried.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: I am sorry my freeness should offend you,
But yet know, I am her chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Play now the market-maid.
And prithee bout thy business.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.l: Well, I shall — that man should be so fooled.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: She a prostitute?
Nay, and to him my troth plight, and my friend;
As possible it is, that heaven and earth
Should be in love together, meet and kiss,
And so cut off all distance: what strange frenzy
Came in this wench's brain, so to surmise?
Were she so base? his nobleness is such,
He would not entertain it for my sake:
Or he so bent? His hot and lust burnt appetite
Would be soon quenched, at the mere contemplation
Of her most pious and religious life.
The girl was much too blame; perhaps her mistress
Hath stirred her anger, by some word or blow,
Which she would thus revenge; not apprehending
at what a high price honour's to be rated;
Or else some one that envies her rare virtue,
Might hire her thus to brand it; or, who knows
But the young wench may fix a thought on me;
And to divert me from her mistress love,
May raise this false aspersion? howsoever,
My thoughts on these two columns fixed are,
She's good as fresh, and purely chaste as fair.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O sir, you are the needle, and if the whole county of Middlesex had been turned to a mere bottle of hay, I had been enjoined to have found you out, or never more returned back to my old master: there's a letter sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I know the hand that superscribed it well;
Stay but till I peruse it, and from me
Thou shalt return an answer.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I shall sir: this is market-day, and here acquaintance commonly meet; and whom have I encountered my gossip pint-pot, and brim full; nay, I mean to drink with you before I part, and how doth all your worshipful kindred? your sister quart, your pater-pottle, (Who was ever a gentleman's fellow) and your old grandsire gallon; they cannot choose but be all in health, since so many healths have been drunk out of them: I could wish them all here, and in no worse state than I see you are in at this present; howsoever gossip, since I have met you hand to hand, I'll make bold to drink to you — nay, either you must pledge me, or get one to do't for you; do you open your mouth towards me? well, I know what you would say; here Roger, to your master and mistress, and all our good friends at home; gramercy gossip, if I should not pledge thee, I were worthy to be turned out to grass, and stand no more at livery: and now in requital of this courtesy I'll begin one health to you and all your society in the oeller, to Peter pipe, Harry hogshead, Bartholomew butt, and little master Randall Rundlet, to Timothy taster, and all your other great and small friends.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: He writes me heat,
That at my discontinuance he's much grieved,
Desiring me, as I have ever rendered
Or him or his, to give him satisfaction
Touching my discontent; and that in person,
By any private meeting.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I sir, 'tis very true, the letter speaks no more
than he wished me to tell you by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Thou art then of his council?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: His privy and please you.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Though ne'er so strict hath been my father's charge,
A little I'll dispense with't, for his love;
Commend me to thy master, tell him from me,
On Monday night (Then will my leisure serve)
I will by heaven's assistance visit him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: On Monday sir:
That's as I remember, just the day before Tuesday.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: But 't will be midnight first, at which late hour,
Please him to let the garden door stand ope,
At that I'll enter; but conditionally,
That neither wife, friend, servant, no third soul
Save him, and thee to whom he trusts this message,
Know of my coming in, or passing out:
When, tell him, I will fully satisfy him
Concerning my forced absence.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I am something oblivious; your message would be the truelier delivered if it were set down in black and white.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I'll call for pen and ink,
And instantly dispatch it.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Now impudence, but steel my face this once,
Although I ne'er blush after; here's the house,
Ho, who's within? What, no man to descend
These innocent gates from knocking?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Who's without there?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: One sir that ever wished your worship's health;
And those few hours I can find time to pray in,
I still remember it.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Gramercy Reignald,
I love all those that wish it: you are the men
Lead merry lives, feast, revel, and carouse;
You feel no tedious hours; time plays with you,
This is your golden age.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: It was, but now sir,
that gold is turned to worse than alchemy,
It will not stand the test; those days are past,
And now our nights come on.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Tell me Reignald, is he returned from sea?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Yes, to our grief already, but we fear
Hereafter, it may prove to all our costs.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Suspects thy master any thing?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Not yet sir;
Now my request is, that your worship being
So near a neighbour, therefore most disturbed,
Would not be first to peach us.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Take my word;
With other neighbours make what peace you can,
I'll not be your accuser.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Worshipful sir;
I shall be still your beadsman; now the business
That I was sent about, the old man my master
Claiming some interest in acquaintance past,
Desires (Might it be no way trouble some)
To take free view of all your house within.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: View of my house? Why 'tis not set to sale,
Nor bill upon the door; look well upon't:
View of my house?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry sir,
He no way doth disable your estate;
As far to buy, as you are loath to sell;
Some alterations in his own he'd make.
And hearing yours by workmen much commended,
He would make that his precedent.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What fancies
Should at this age possess him; knowing the cost,
That he should dream of building.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: 'Tis supposed,
He hath late found a wife out for his son;
Now sir, to have him near him, and that nearness
Too, without trouble, though beneath one roof,
Yet parted in two families; he would build
And make what's picked, a perfect quadrangle,
Proportioned just with yours, were you so pleased,
To make it his example.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Willingly; I will but order some few things within,
And then attend his coming.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Most kind coxcomb,
Great Alexander, and Agathocles,
Caesar, and others, have been famed, they say.
And magnified for high facinorous deeds;
Why claim not I, an equal place with them?
Or rather a precedent: these commanded
Their subjects, and their servants; I my master,
And every way his equals, where I please,
Lead by the nose along; they placed their burdens
On horses, mules, and camels; ay, old men
Of strength and wit, load with my knavery,
Till both their backs and brains ache; yet poor animals,
They ne'er complain of weight; o are you come sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: I made what haste I could.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: And brought the warrant?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: See here, I have't.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, but speak, runs it
Both without bail and mainprize?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Nay, it carries both form and power.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Then I shall warrant him;
I have been yonder sir,

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: And what says he?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Like one that offers you
Free ingress, view and regress, at your pleasure;
As to his worthy landlord.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Was that all?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: He spoke to me, that I would speak to you,
To speak unto your son; and then again,
To speak to him, that he would speak to you;
You would release his bargain.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: By no means,
Men must advise before they part with land,
Not after to repent it; 'tis most just,
That such as hazard, and disburse their stocks,
Should take all gains and profits that accrue,
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Ricot again walking before the gate.
sp.l: As well in sale of houses, as in barter,
And traffic of all other merchandise.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: See in acknowledgement of a tenant's duty,
He attends you at the gate; salute him sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: My worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now as I live, all my best thoughts and wishes
Impart with yours, in your so safe return;
Your servant tells me, you have great desire
To take survey of this my house within.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Be't sir, no trouble to you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: None, enter boldly;
With as much freedom, as it were your own.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: As it were mine; why Reignald, is it not?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Lord sir, that in extremity of grief,
You'll add unto vexation; see you not
How sad he's on the sudden,

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: I observe it.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: To part with that which he hath kept so long;
Especially his inheritance: now as you love
Goodness, and honesty, torment him not
With the least word of purchase.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Counselled well;
Thou teachest me humanity.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Will you enter?
Or shall I call a servant, to conduct you
Through every room and chamber?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: By no means;
I fear we are too much troublesome of ourselves.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: See what a goodly gate?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: It likes me well.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: What brave carved posts; who knows but here,
In time sir, you may keep your shrievalty;
And I be one oth' sergeants.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: They are well carved.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And cost me a good price sir, take your pleasure,
I have business in the town.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Poor man, I pity him;
H'ath not the heart to stay and see you come,
As 'twere, to take possession; look that way sir,
What goodly fair bay windows?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Wondrous stately.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: And what a gallery, how costly seeled;
What painting round about?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Every fresh object to good, adds betterness.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Terraced above, and how below supported; do they please you?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: All things beyond opinion; trust me Reignald,
I'll not forgo the bargain, for more gain
Than half the price it cost me.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: If you would? I should not suffer you; was not the
Money due to the usurer, took upon good ground,
That proved well built upon? We were no fools
That knew not what we did.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: It shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Please you to trust me with't, I'll see't discharged.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: He hath my promise, and I'll do't myself:
Never could son have better pleased a father,
Then in this purchase: hie thee instantly
Unto my house ith' country, give him notice
Of my arrive, and bid him with all speed
Post hither.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Ere I see the warrant served?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: It shall be thy first business; for my soul
Is not at peace, till face to face, I approve
His husbandry, and much commend his thrift;
Nay, without pause, be gone.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: But a short journey;
For he's not far, that I am sent to seek:
I have got the start, the best part of the race
Is run already, what remains, is small,
And tire now, I should but forfeit all.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Make haste, I do entreat thee.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This is the garden gate; and here am I set to stand sentinel, and to attend the coming of young master Geraldine: master dalavill's gone to his chamber; my mistress to hers; 'tis now about midnight; a banquet prepared, bottles of wine in readiness, all the whole household at their rest; and no creature by this, honestly stirring, saving I and my old master; he in a bye chamber, prepared of purpose for their private meeting; and I here to play the watchEnter young Geraldine.man, against my will; chavelah, stand; who goes there?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The word?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Honest Roger.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: That's the word indeed; you have leave to pass freely without calling my corporal.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: How go the affairs within?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: According to promise, the business is composed, and the servants disposed, my young mistress reposed, my old master according as you proposed, attends you if you be exposed to give him meeting; nothing in the way being interposed, to transpose you to the least danger: and this I dare be deposed, if you will not take my word, as I am honest Roger.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Thy word shall be my warrant, but secured
Most in thy master's promise, on which building;
By this known way I enter.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay, by your leave, I that was late but a plain sentinel,
Will now be your captain conductor: follow me.

div.stage: Table and stools set out; lights: a banquet, wine. Enter master Wincott.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: I wonder whence this strangeness should proceed,
Or wherein I, or any of my house,
Should be th' occasion of the least distaste;
Now, as I wish him well, it troubles me;
But now the time grows on, from his own mouth
To be resolved; and I hope satisfied:
Sir, as I live, of all my friends to me
Most wishedly, you are welcome: take that chair,
I this: nay, I intreat no compliment;
Attend — fill wine.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Till the mouths of the bottles yawn directly upon the floor, and the bottoms turn their rails up to the ceiling; whilst there's any blood in their bellies, I'll not leave them.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: I first salute you thus.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: It could not come
From one whom I more honour; sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay, since my master begun it, I'll see't go round
To all three.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Now give us leave.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Talk you by yourselves, whilst I find something to say to this: I have a tale no tell him shall make his stony heart relent.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Now, first sir your attention I entreat;
Next, your belief that what I speak is just,
Maugre all contradiction.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Both are granted.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Then I proceed; with due acknowledgement
Of all your more than many courtesies:
You've been my second father, and your wife,
my noble and chaste mistress; all your servants
At my command; and this your bounteous table,
As free and common as my father's house;
Neither 'gainst any, or the least of these,
Can I commence just quarrel.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: What might then be
The cause of this constraint, in thus absenting
Yourself from such as love you?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Out of many,
I will propose some few: the care I have
Of your (As yet unblemished) renown;
The untouched honour of your virtuous wife;
And (Which I value least, yet dear too)
My own fair reputation.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: How can these, in any way be questioned?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: O dear sir,
Bad tongues have been too busy with us all;
Of which I never yet had time to think,
But with sad thoughts and griefs unspeakable:
It hath been whispered by some wicked ones,
But loudly thundered in my father's ears,
By some that have maligned our happiness;
(Heaven, if it can brook slander, pardon them)
That this my customary coming hither,
Hath been to base and sordid purposes:
To wrong your bed; injure her chastity;
And be mine own undoer: which, how false?

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: As heaven is true, I know't.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Now this calumny
Arriving first unto my father's ears,
His easy nature was induced to think,
That these things might perhaps be possible:
I answered him, as I would do to heaven:
And cleared myself in his suspicious thoughts,
As truly, as the high all-knowing judge
Shall of these stains acquit me; which are merely
Aspersions and untruths: the good old man
Possessed with my sincerity, and yet careful
Of your renown, her honour, and my fame;
To stop the-worst that scandal could inflict;
and to prevent false rumours charges me,
The cause removed, to take away the effect;
Which only could be, to forbear your house;
And this upon his blessing: you hear all.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: And I of all acquit you: this your absence,
With which my love most cauclled; orators
In your behalf. Had such things passed betwixt you,
Not threats nor chidings could have driven you hence:
It pleads in your behalf, and speaks in hers;
And arms me with a double confidence,
Both of your friendship, and her loyalty:
I am happy in you both, and only doubtful
Which of you two doth most impart my love:
You shall not hence tonight .

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Pray pardon sir.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: You are in your lodging.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: But my father's charge.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: My conjuration shall dispense with that;
You may be up as early as you please;
But hence tonight you shall not.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: You are powerful.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: This night, of purpose, I have parted beds,
Feigning myself not well, to give you meeting;
Nor can be ought suspected by my wife,
I have kept all so private: now 'tis late,
I'll steal up to my rest, but howsoever,
Let's not be strange in our writing, that way daily
We may confer without the least suspect,
In spite of all such base calumnious tongues;
So, now goodnight sweet friend

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: May he that made you
So just and good, still guard you. Not to bed,
So I perhaps might oversleep myself,
And then my tardy waking might betray me
To the more early household; thus as I am,
I'll rest me on this pillow; but in vain,
I find no sleep can fasten on mine eyes,
There are in this disturbed brain of mine
So many mutinous fancies: this, to me,
Will be a tedious night; how shall I spend it?
No book that I can spy? no company?
A little let me recollect myself;
O, what more wished company can I find,
Suiting the apt occasion, time and place;
Then the sweet contemplation of her beauty;
And the fruition too, time may produce,
Of what is yet lent out? 'tis a sweet lady,
And every way accomplished: hath mere accident
Brought me thus near, and I not visit her?
Should it arrive here are, perhaps might breed
Our lasting separation; for 'twixt lovers,
No quarrel's to unkindness; sweet opportunity
Offers prevention, and invites me to't:
The house is known to me, the stairs and rooms;
The way unto her chamber frequently
Trodden by me at midnight, and all hours:
How joyful to her would a meeting be,
So strange and unexpected; shadowed too
Beneath the veil of night; I am resolved
To give her visitation, in that place
Where we have passed deep vows, her bedchamber:
My fiery love this darkness makes seem bright,
And and this the path that leads to my delight.
sp.stage: He goes in at one door, and comes out at another.
sp.l: And this the gate unto't; I'll listen first,
Before too rudely I disturb her rest:
And gentle breathing; ha? she's sure awake,
For in the bed two whisper, and their voices
Appear to me unequal; — one a woman's —
And hers; — th' other should be no maids tongue,
It bears too big a tone; and hark, they laugh;
(Damnation) but list further; tother sounds —
Like — 'tis the same false perjured traitor, Dalavill,
To friend and goodness: unchaste impious woman,
False to all faith, and true conjugal love;
There's met, a serpent and a crocodile;
A Sinon and a Circe: o, to what
May I compare you? — but my sword,
I'll act a noble execution,
On two unmatched for sordid villainy: —
I left it in my chamber, and thanks heaven
That I did to; it hath prevented me
From playing a base hangman: since securely
Whilst I, although for many, yet less faults,
Strive hourly to repent me; I once loved her,
And was to him entired; although I pardon,
Heaven will find time to punish, I'll not stretch
My just revenge so far, as once by 〈◊〉
To make your brazen impudence to blush;
Damn on, revenge too great; and to suppress
Your souls yet lower, without hope to rise
Heap Ossa upon Pelion: you have made me
To hate my very country, because here bred:
Near two such monsters; first I'll leave this house,
And then my fathers; next I'll take my leave,
Both of this clime and nation, travel till
Age snow upon this head: my passions now,
Are unexpressable, I'll end them thus:
Ill man, bad woman, your unheard of treachery,
This unjust censure, on a just man give,
To seek out place, where no two 〈◊〉 live.

div.stage: Enter Dalavill as a night - 〈◊〉: wift in a nighttyre, as 〈◊〉 from bed.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: A happy morning now betide you lady,
To equal the content of a sweet night.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It hath been to my wish, and your desire:
And this your coming by pretended
Unto my sister Pru. cuts of suspicion
Of any such converse 'twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: It hath been wisely carried.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: One thing troubles me.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: What's that my dearest?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why your friend Geraldine,
Should on the sudden thus absent himself?
Has he had think you no intelligence.
Of these our private meetings.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: No, on my soul,
For therein hath my brain exceeded yours;
I studying to engross you to myself,
Of his continued absence have been cause
yet he of your affection no way jealous,
Or of my friendship — how the plot was cast,
You at our better leisure shall partake;
The air grows cold, have care unto your health,
Suspicious eyes are o'er us, that yet sleep,
But with the dawn, will open; sweet retire you
To your warm sheets; I now to fill my own,
That have this night been empty.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You advise well;
O might this kiss dwell ever on thy lips,
In my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Doubt it not I pray,
Whilst day frights night, and night pursues the day:
Good morrow.

div.stage: Enter Reignald, Y. Lionell, Blanda, scapha, rioter. and two gallants, Reig. with a key in his hand.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Now is the goal delivery; through this back gate
Shift for yourselves, I here unprison all.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: But tell me, how shall we dispose ourselves?
We are as far to seek now, as the first;
What is it to reprieve us for few hours,
And now to suffer, better had it been
At first, to have stood the trial, so by this,
We might have passed our penance.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.l: Sweet Reignald.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Honest rogue.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: If now thou failest us, than we are lost for ever,

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: This same sweet Reignald, and this honest rogue,
Hath been the burgess, under whose protection
You all this while have lived, free from arrests,
But now, the sessions of my power's broke up,
And you exposed to actions, warrants, writs;
For all the hellish rabble are broke loose,
Of sergeants, sheriffs, and bailiffs,

sp.speaker: O●●.
sp.l: Guard us heaven,

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I tell you as it is; nay, I myself
That have been your protector, now as subject
To every varlet's pestle, for you know
How I am engaged with you — at whose suit sir.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Why didst thou start.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I was afraid some catchpole stood behind me,
To clap me on the shoulder.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: No such thing; yet I protest
Thy fear did fright us all.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I knew your guilty consciences.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: No brain left?

sp.speaker: Ela.
sp.l: No crotchet for my sake?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: One kiss then sweet,
Thus shall my crotchets, and your kisses meet.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Nay, tell us what to trust too.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Lodge yourselves
In the next tavern, there's the cash that's left,
Go, health it freely for my good success;
Nay, drown it all, let not a taster scape
To be consumed in rotgut; I have begun,
And I will stand the period.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: Bravely spoke.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Or perish in the conflict.

sp.speaker: Rioter
sp.l: Worthy Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Well, if he now come off well, fox you all;
Go, call for wine; for singlly of myself
I will oppose all danger; but I charge you,
When I shall faint or find myself distressed;
If I like brave Orlando, wind my horn,
Make haste unto my rescue.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: And die in't.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Well hast thou spoke my noble Charlemagne,
With these thy peers about thee.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: May good speed
Attend thee still.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: The end still crowns the deed.

div.stage: Enter old Lionell, and the first owner of the house.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: Sir sir, your threats nor warrants, can fright me;
My honesty and innocency's known
Always to have been unblemished; would you could
As well approve your own integrity,
As I shall doubtless acquit myself
Of this surmised murder.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Rather surrender
The price I paid, and take into thy hands
This haunted mansion, or I'll prosecute
My wrongs, even to the utmost of the law,
Which is no less than death.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: I'll answer all
Old Lionell, both to thy shame and scorn;
This for thy menaces.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: This is the house, but where's the noise that was wont to be in't? I am sent hither, to deliver a note, to two young gentlemen that here keep revelrout; I remember it, since the last massacre of meat that was made in't; but it seems, that the great storm that was raised then, is chaste now; I have other notes to deliver, one to master Rycott — and — I shall think on them all in order; my old master makes a great feast, for the parting of young master Geraldine, who is presently upon his departure for travel, and the better to grace it, hath invited many of his neighbours and friends; where will be old master Geraldine — his son, and I cannot tell how many; but this is strange, the gates shut up at this time a day, belike they are all drunk and laid to sleep, if they be, I'll wake them, with a murrain.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What desperate fellow's this, that ignorant
Of his own danger, thunders at these gates?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ho, Reignald, riotous Reignald, revelling Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.l: What madness doth possess thee, honest friend,
To touch that hammers handle?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: What madness doth possess thee, honest friend,
To ask me such a question?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Nay, stir not you?

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: Not I; the game begins.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: How dost thou, art thou well?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes very well, I thank you, how do you sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: No alteration; what change about thee?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Not so much change about me at this time,
As to change you a shilling into two tasters.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Yet I advise thee fellow, for thy good,
Stand further from the gate.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And I advise thee friend, for thine own good, stand not betwixt me and the gate, but give me leave to deliver my errand; ho, Reignald, you mad rascal.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: In vain thou thunderest at these silent doors,
Where no man dwells to answer, saving ghosts,
Furies, and sprights.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ghosts; indeed there has been much walking, in and about the house after midnight.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: Strange noise oft heard.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Yes, terrible noise, that none of the neighbours could take any rest for it, I have heard it myself.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: You hear this; here's more witness.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Which you shall dear answer — whooping.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: And hollowing.

sp.speaker: Old. Lio.
sp.l: And shouting.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: And crying out, till the whole house rung again.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Which thou hast heard?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Oftener than I have toes and singers.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Thou wilt be deposed of this?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll be sworn to't, and that's as good.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Very good still; yet you are innocent:
Shall I entreat thee friend, to avouch as much
Here by, to the next justice.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll take my soldier's oath on't.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: A soldier's oath, what's that?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My corporal oath; and you know sir, a corporal is an office belonging to a soldier.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Yet you are clear?
Murder will come to light.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: So will your gullery too.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: They say my old master's come home; I'll see if he will turn me out of doors, as the young man has done: I have laid rods in piss for somebody, scape Reignald as he can, and with more freedom than I dust late, I boldly now dare knock.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: More madmen yet; I think since my last voyage,
Half of the world's turned frantic: what dost mean,
Or longest thou to be blasted?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O sir, you are welcome home; 'twas time to come
Ere all was gone to havoc.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: My old servant? before I shall demand of further business. Resolve me why thou thunderest at these doors,
sp.l: Where thou knowest none inhabits?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Are they gone sir?
'Twas well yet they have left the house behind;
For all the furniture, to a bare bench,
I am sure is spent and wasted.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Where's my son,
That Reignald posting for him with such speed,
Brings him not from the country?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Country sir?
'Tis a thing they know not; here they feast,
Dice, drink, and drab; the company they keep,
Cheaters and roaring-ladds, and these attended
By bawds and queans: your son hath got a strumpet,
On whom he spends all that your sparing left,
And here they keep court; to whose damned abuses,
Reignald gives all encouragement.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But stay stay;
No living soul hath for these six months space
Here entered, but the house stood desolate.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Last week I am sure, so late, and th' other day,
Such revels were here kept.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: And by my son?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yes, and his servant Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: And this house at all not haunted?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Save sir with such sprights.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: This murder will come out.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But see, in happy time here comes my
Neighbour of whom he bought this mansion; he I am sure
More amply can resolve me: I pray sir,
What sums of moneys have you late received
Of my young son?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Of him? None I assure you.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What of my servant Reignald?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But device
What to call less than nothing, and that sum
I will confess received.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Pray sir, be serious;
I do confess myself indebted to you,
A hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: You may do well to pay't then, for here's witness sufficient of your words.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.p: I speak no more than what I purpose; lust so much I owe you, and ere I sleep will tender.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I shall be as ready to receive it, and as willing,
As you can be to pay't.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But provided,
You will confess seven hundred pounds received
Before hand of my son?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But by your favour;
Why should I yield seven hundred received
Of them I never dealt with? Why? For what?
What reason? What condition? Where or when
Should such a sum be paid me?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Why? For this bargain: and for what? This house,
Reason? Because you sold it: the conditions? Such
As were agreed between you: where and when?
That only hath escaped me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Madness all.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Was I not brought to take free view thereof,
As of mine own possession?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I confess;
Your servant told me you had found out a wife
Fit for your son, and that you meant to build;
Desired to take a friendly view of mine,
To make it your example: but for selling,
I tell you sir, my wants be not so great,
To change my house to coin.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Spare sir your anger,
And turn it into pity; neighbours and friends,
I am quite lost, was never man so fooled,
And by a wicked servant; shame and blushing
Will not permit to tell the manner how,
Lest I be made ridiculous to all:
My fears are to inherit what's yet left;
He hath made my son away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: That's my fear too.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Friends, as you would commiserate a man
Deprived at once, both of his wealth and son;
And in his age, by one I ever tendered
More like a son than servant: by imagining
My case were yours, have feeling of my griefs
And help to apprehend him;
Furnish me with cords and fetters,
I will lay him safe in prison within prison.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: We'll assist you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: And all;
But not to do the least hurt to my old friend Reginald.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: His legs will be as nimble as his brain,
And 'twill be difficult to seize the slave,
sp.stage: Enter Reignald with a horn in his pocket: they withdraw behind the arras.
sp.l: Yet your endeavours, pray peace, here ho comes.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: My heart misgives, for 'tis not possible
But that in all these windings and indents
I shall be found at last: I'll take that course
That men both troubled and affrighted do,
Heap doubt on doubt, and as combustions rise,
Try if from many I can make my peace,
And work mine own atonement.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Stand you close,
Be not yet seen, but at your best advantage
Hand him, and bind him fast: whilst I dissemble
As if I yet knew nothing.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I suspect
And find there's trouble in my master's looks;
Therefore I must not trust myself too far
Within his fingers.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Reignald?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Worshipful sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What says my son ith' country?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: That tomorrow,
Early ith' morning, he'll attend your pleasure,
And do as all such duteous children ought;
Demand your blessing sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Well, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I do not like his countenance.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But Reignald? I suspect the honesty
And the good meaning of my neighbour here,
Old master Ricott; meeting him but now,
And having some discourse about the house,
He makes all strange, and tells me in plain terms,
He knows of no such matter.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Tell me that sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: I tell thee as it is:
Nor that such moneys, took up at use, were ever tendered him
On any such conditions.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I cannot blame your worship to be pleasant,
Knowing at what an underrate we bought it, but you ever
Were a most merry gentleman.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: (Impudent slave)
But Reignald, he not only doth demi it,
But offers to depose himself and servants,
No such thing ever was.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Now heaven, to see to what this world's grown too.
I will make him —

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Nay more, this man will not confess the murder.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Which both shall dear answer; you have warrant
For him already; but for the other sir,
If he deny it, he had better —

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Appear gentlemen,
'Tis a fit time to take him.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I discover the ambush that's laid for me.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Come nearer Reignald.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: First sir resolve me one thing, amongst other merchandise
Bought in your absence by your son and me,
We engrossed a great commodity of combs,
And how many sorts think you?

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: You might buy
Some of the bones of fishes, some of beasts,
Box-combs, and ivory 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: But besides these, we have for horses sir,
Mane-combs, and curry-combs; now sir for men,
We have head-combs, 〈◊〉 - combs, I and coxcombs too;
Take view of them at your pleasure, whilst for my part,
I thus bestow myself.

div.stage: They all appear 〈…〉 and shackles, whilst he goes up.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Well said Reignald, nobly put off Reignald,
Look to thyself Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Why dost thou climb thus?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Only to practise
The nimbleness of my arms and legs,
Ere they prove your cords and fetters.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Why to that place?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Why harbour long, and now it must be my sanctuary; dispute now, and I'll answer.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: Villain
To challenge me of murder?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: O sir, the man you killed is alive at this present to justify it: I am, quoth he, a transmarine by birth —

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Why, challenge me receipt of moneys, and to give abroad, that I had sold my house?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Why? because sir,
Could I have purchased houses at that rate,
I had meant to have bought all London.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes, and Middlesex too, and I would have been thy half Reignald.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Yours are great,
My wrongs insufferable; as first, to fright me
From mine own dwelling, till they had consumed
The whole remainder of the little left;
Besides, out of my late stock got at sea,
Discharge the clamorous usurer; make me accuse
This man of murder; be at charge of warrants;
And challenging this my worthy neighbour of
Forswearing sums he never yet received;
Fool me, to think my son that had spent all,
Had by his thrift bought land; I and him too,
To open all the secrets of his house
To me, a stranger, on thou insolent villain,
What to all these canst answer?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Guilty, guilty.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But to my son's death, what thou slave?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Not guilty.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Produce him then; ith' mean time, and —
Honest friends, get ladders.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Yes, and come down in your own ropes.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: I'll fetch a piece and shoot him.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: So the warrant in my master's pocket, will serve for my murder; and ever after shall my ghost haunt this house.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: And I will say like Reignald,
This ghost and I am friends.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Bring faggots, I'll set fire upon the house,
Rather than this endure.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: To burn houses is felony, and I'll not out
Till be fired out; but since I am besieged thus,
I'll summon supplies unto my rescue.

div.stage: He windes a horn. Enter young Lionell, rioter, two gallants Blanda, etc.

sp.speaker: Y. Lie.
sp.l: Before you chide, first hear me, next your blessing,
that on my knees I beg; I have but done,
Like misspent youth, which after wit dear bought,
Turns his eyes inward, sorry and ashamed;
These things in which I have offended most,
Had I not proved, I should have thought them still
Essential things, delights perdurable;
Which now I find mere shadows, toys and dreams,
Now hated more than erst I doted on;
Best natures, are soonest wrought on; such was mine;
As I the offences, so the offenders throw
Here at your feet, to punish as you please;
You have but paid so much as I have wasted,
To purchase to yourself a thrifty son;
Which I from henceforth, vow.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: See what fathers are,
That can three years offences, foul ones too,
Thus in a minute pardon; and thy faults
Upon myself chastise, in these my tears;
Ere this submission, I had cast thee off;
Rise in my new adoption: but for these —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The one you have nothing to do withal, here's his ticket for his discharge; another for you sir, to summon you to my master's feast, for you, and you, where I charge you all to appear, upon his displeasure, and your own apperils.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: This is my friend the one I loved,
Only because they have been dear to him
That now will strive to be more dear to you;
Vouchsafe their pardon.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: All dear, to me indeed, for I have paid for't soundly,
Yet for the sake, I am atoned with all; only that wanton.
Her, and her company, abandon quite;
So doing, we are friends.

sp.speaker: Y. Lie.
sp.l: A just condition, and willingly subscribed to.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But for that villain; I am now devising
What shame, what punishment remarkable,
To inflict on him.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Why master? Have I laboured;
Plotted, contrived, and all this while for you,
And will you leave me to the whip and stocks;
Not mediate my peace.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Sirrah come down.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Not till my pardon's sealed, I'll rather stand here
Like a statue, in the forefront of your house
For ever; like the picture of dame fortune
Before the fortune playhouse.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: If I have here
But any friend amongst you, join with me
In this petition.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Good sir, for my sake, I resolved you truly
Concerning whooping, the noise, the walking; and the sprights,
And for a need, can show you a ticket for him too.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: I impute my wrongs rather to knavish cunning,
Than least pretended malice.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What he did,
Was but for his young master, I allow it
Rather as sports of wit, than injuries;
No other prey esteem them.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Even as freely,
As you forget my quarrels made with you;
Raised from the errors first begot by him;
I here remit all free; I now am calm,
But had I seized upon him in my spleen —

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I knew that, therefore this was my invention,
For policy's the art still of prevention.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Come down then Reignald, first on your hands and feet, and then on your knees to your master; now gentlemen, what do you say to your inviting to my master's feast.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: We will attend him.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Nor do I love to break good company;
For master Wincott is my worthy friend,
And old acquaintance; o thou crafty wagstring,
And couldst thou thus delude me? But we are friends;
Nor gentlemen, let not what's here to past,
In your least thoughts disable my estate;
This my last voyage hath made all things good,
With surplus too; be that your comfort son:
Well Reignald — but no more.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: I was the fox,
But I from henceforth, will no more the coxcomb
, put upon your pate.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Let's walk gentlemen

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter old Geraldine, and young Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Son, let me tell you, you are ill advised;
And doubly to be blamed, by undertaking
Unnecessary travel; grounding no reason
For such a rash and giddy enterprise:
What profit aim you at, you have not reaped;
What novelty affords the Christian world,
Of which your view hath not participated
In a full measure; can you either better
Your language or experience? Your self-will
Hath only purpose to deprive a father
Of a loved son, and many noble friends,
Of your much wished acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: O, dear sir,
Do not, I do entreat you, repent you
Of your free grant; which with such care and study.
I have so long, so often laboured for.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Say that may be dispensed with, show me reason
Why you desire to steal out of your country,
Like some malefactor that had forfeited
His life and freedom; here's a worthy gentleman
Hath for your sake invited many guests,
To his great charge, only to take of you
A parting leave; you send him word you cannot,
After, you may not come: had not my urgence,
Almost compulsion, driven you to his house,
Th' unkindness might have forfeited your love,
And razed you from his will; in which he hath given you,
A fair and large estate; yet you of all this strangeness,
Show no sufficient ground.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Then understand;
The ground thereof took his first birth from you;
'Twas you first charged me to forbear the house,
And that upon your blessing: let it not then
Offend you sir, if I so great a charge
Have strived to keep so strictly.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: Me perhaps,
you may appease, and with small difficulty.
Because a father; but how satisfy
Their dear, and on your part, unmerited love?
But this your last obedience may salve all:
We now grow near the house.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Whose doors, to me,
Appear as horrid as the gates of hell:
Where shall I borrow patience, or from whence?
sp.stage: Enter Wincott, wife, Ricott, the two lionells, owner, Dalavill, Prudentilla, Reignald, rioter.
sp.l: To give a meeting to this viperous brood,
Of friend and mistress.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: You've entertained me with a strange discourse
Of your man's knavish wit, but I rejoice,
That in your safe return, all ends so well:
Most welcome you, and you, and indeed all;
To whom I am bound, that at so short a warning,
Thus friendly, you will deign to visit me.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: It seems my absence hath begotten some sport,
Thank my kind servant here.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Not so much worth sir.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: But though their riots tripped at my estate,
They have not quite o'erthrown it.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.p: But see gentlemen, these whom we most expected, come at length; this I proclaim the master of the feast,
sp.l: In which to express the bounty of my love,
I'll show myself no niggard.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Your choice favours,
I still taste in abundance.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Methinks it would not misbecome me sir,
To chide your absence; that have made yourself,
To us, so long a stranger.

div.stage: He turns away sad, as not being minded.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Pardon me sir,
That have not yet, since your return from sea,
Voted the least fit opportunity,
To entertain you with a kind salute.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: Most kindly sir I thank you.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Methinks friend,
You should expect green rushes to be strowed,
after such discontinuance.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Mistress Pru,
I have not seen you long, but greet you thus,
May you be lady of a better husband
Than I expect a wife.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: I like that greeting:
Nay, enter gentlemen; dinner perhaps
Is not yet ready, but the time we stay,
We'll find some fresh discourse to spend away.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Not speak to me? nor once vouchsafe an answer,
But sleight me with a poor and base neglect?
No, nor so much as cast an eye on her,
Or least regard, though in a seeming show
She courted a reply? 'twixt him and her,
Nay him and me, this was not wont to be;
If she have brain to apprehend as much
As I have done, she'll quickly find it out:
Now as I live, as our affections meet,
So our conceits, and she hath singled him
To some such purpose: I'll retire myself.
Not interrupt their conference.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are sad sir.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I know no cause.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Then can I show you some;
Who could be otherways, to leave a father
So careful, and each way so provident?
To leave so many, and such worthy friends?
To abandon your own country? These are some,
Nor do I think you can be much the merrier
For my sake?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Now your tongue speaks oracles;
For all the rest are nothing, 'tis for you,
Only for you I cannot.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: So I thought;
Why then have you been all this while so strange?
Why will you travel? suing a divorce
Betwixt us, of a love inseparable;
For here shall I be left as desolate
unto a frozen, almost widowed bed;
Warmed only in that future, stored in you;
For who can in your absence comfort me?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Shall my oppressed sufferance yet break forth
Into impatience, or endure her more?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: But since by no persuasion, no entreats,
Your settled obstinacy can be swal'd,
Though you seem desperate of your own dear life,
Have care of mine, for it exists in you.
O sir, should you miscarry I were lost,
Lost and forsaken; then by our past vows,
And by this hand once given me, by these rears,
Which are but springs begetting greater floods,
I do beseech thou, my dear Geraldine,
Look to thy safety, and preserve thy health;
Have care into what company you fall;
Travel not late, and cross no dangerous seas;
For till heavens bless me in thy safe return,
How will this poor heart suffer?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I had thought
Long since the Syrens had been all destroyed;
But one of them I find survives in her;
She almost makes me question what I know,
An heretic unto my own belief:
O thou mankind's seducer.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: What? no answer?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Yes, thou hast spoke to me in showers,
I will reply in thunder; thou adultress,
That hast more poison in thee then the serpent,
Who was the first that did corrupt thy sex,
The devil.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: To whom speaks the man?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: To thee, falsest of all that ever man termed fair;
Hath impudence so stooled thy smooth soft skin,
It cannot blush? Or sin so obdured thy heart,
It doth not quake and tremble? Search thy conscience,
There thou shalt find a thousand clamorous tongues
To speak as loud as mine doth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Save from yours,
I hear no noise at all.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: I'll play the doctor
To open thy deaf ears; Monday the ninth
Of the last month; canst thou remember that?
That night more black in thy abhorred sin,
Then in the gloomy darkness; that the time.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Monday?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Wouldst thou the place know? Thy polluted chamber,
So often, witness of my sinless vows;
Wouldst thou the person? One not worthy name,
Yet to torment thy guilty soul the more,
I'll tell him thee, that monster Dalavill;
Wouldst thou your bawd know? Midnight, that the hour;
The very words thou spoke? Now what would Geraldine
Say, if he saw us here? To which was answered,
Tush he's a coxcomb, fit to be so fooled:
No blush? What, no faint fever on thee yet?
How hath thy black sins changed thee? Thou Medusa,
Those hairs that late appeared like golden wires,
Now crawl with snakes and adders; thou art ugly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And yet my glass, till now, near told me so;
Who gave you this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Only he,
That pitying such an innocenti●●s mine,
Should by two such delinquents be betrayed,
He brought me to that place by miracle;
And made mean ear witness of all this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: But think what thou hast lost
To forfeit me; I not withstanding these,
(So fixed was my love and vulnerable)
I kept this from thy husband, nay all ears,
With thy transgressions smothering mine own wrongs,
In hope of thy repentance

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Which begins thus low upon my knees.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: Tush, bow to heaven,
Which thou hast most offended; alas,
Save in such (Scarce unheard of) treachery,
Most sinful like thyself;
Wherein, o wherein, hath my unspotted and unbounded love
Deserved the least of these? Sworn to be made a stale
for term of life; and all this for my goodness;
Die, and die soon, acquit me of my oath,
But prithee die repentant; farewell ever,
'Tis thou, and only thou hast banished me,
Both from my friends and country.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O, I am lost.

div.stage: Enter Dalavill meeting young Geraldine going out.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Why how now, what's the business?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.p: Go take her up, whom thou hast oft thrown down, villain.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: That was no language from a friend,
It had too harsh an accent; but how's this?
My mistress thus low cast upon the earth
Gravelling and breathless, mistress, lady, sweet —

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O tell me if thy name be Geraldine,
Thy very looks will kill me?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: View me well,
I am no such man; see, I am Dalavill.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Thou'rt than a devil, that presents before me
My horrid sins; persuades me to despair;
When he like a good angel sent from heaven,
Besought me of repentance; swell sick heart,
Even till thou burst the ribs that bound thee in;
So, there's one string cracked, flow, and flow high,
Even till thy blood distil out of mine eyes,
To witness my great sorrow.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: Faint again,
Some help within there, no attendant near?
Thus to expire, in this I am more wretched,
Than all the sweet fruition of her love
Before could make me happy.

div.stage: Enter Wincott old Geraldine, young Geraldine, the two lionells, Ricott, owner, Prudentilla, Reignald, clown.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: What was he clamoured so loud,
To mingle with our mirth this terror
And affright?

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: See sir, your wife in these my arms expiring.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: My sister?

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Support her, and by all means possible
Provide for her dear safety.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: See, she recovers.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Woman, look up.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O sir, your pardon;
Convey me to my chamber, I am sick,
Sick even to death, away thou sycophant,
Out of my sight, I have besides thyself,
Too many sins about me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: My sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Dal.
sp.l: The storm's coming, I must provide for harbour.

sp.speaker: Old Lio.
sp.l: What strange and sudden alteration's this,
How quickly is this clear day overcast,
But such and so uncertain are all things,
That dwell beneath the moon.

sp.speaker: Y. Lio.
sp.l: A woman's qualm,
Frailties that are inherent to her sex,
Soon sick, and soon recovered.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: If she misfare,
I am a man more wretched in her loss,
Then had I forfeited life and estate;
She was so good a creature.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.l: I the like
Suffered, when I my wife brought unto her grave;
So you, when you were first a widower,
Come arm yourself with patience.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: These are casualties
That are not new, but common.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Burying of wives,
As stale as shifting shifts, or for some servants,
To flout and gull their masters.

sp.speaker: Own.
sp.l: Best to send
And see how her fit holds her.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Sir, my sister
In these few lines commends her last to you,
For she is now no more; what's therein writ,
Save heaven and you, none knows, this she desired
You would take view of; and with these words expired.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: She hath made one then a free release,
Of all the debts I owed her.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: My fear is beyond pardon, Dalavill
Hath played the villain, but for Geraldine,
He hath been each way noble — love him still,
My peace already I have made with heaven;
O be not you at war with me; my honour
Is in your hands to punish, or preserve;
I am now confessed, and only Geraldine
Hath wrought on me this unexpected good;
The ink I write with, I wish had been my blood,
To witness me repentance — Dalavill?
Where's he? Go seek him out.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I shall, I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: The wills of dead folk should be still obeyed;
However false to me, I'll not reveal't;
Where heaven forgives, I pardon gentlemen,
I know you all commiserate my loss;
I little thought this feast should have been turned
Into a funeral; what's the news of him?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: He went presently to the stable, put the saddle upon his horse, put his foot into the stirrup, clapped his spurs into his sides, and away he's galloped, as if he were to ride a race for a wager.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: All our ill lucks go with him, farewell he;
But all my best of wishes wait on you,
As my chief friend; this meeting that was made
Only to take of you a parting leave,
Shall now be made a marriage of our love,
Which none save only death shall separate.

sp.speaker: Y. Ger.
sp.l: It calls me from all travel, and from henceforth,
With my country I am friends.

sp.speaker: Winc.
sp.l: The lands that I have left,
You lend me for the short space of my life;
As soon as heaven calls me, they call you lord;
First feast, and after mourn; we'll like some gallants
That bury thrifty fathers, think't no sin,
To wear blacks without, but other thoughts within.
